title: theresa may commons statement brexit plan b
story: The Prime Minister insisted that he had listened to the concerns of MPs and her policy had changed, but failed to bring forward anything new at all.After her deal was overwhelmingly slapped down by MPs last week, the PM was forced back to the Commons within three days to say what she would do next.But she failed to say anything dferent today, instead promising yet again to continue talks with MPs and discuss how to fix the hated Northern Irish border backstop.Labour MP Stella Creasy said this afternoon: Nothing has changed. No progress on what Brexit means.And veteran MP Hillary Benn blasted her for failing to listen to what opposition politicians wanted, saying: While her door may have been open, her mind remains closed.The PM told MPs:Mrs May said she would be speaking to the DUP this week and other colleagues, and will go back to Brussels to tell them what is needed to get the deal over the line.We will work to identy how we can ensure that our commitment to no hard border in Northern Ireland and Ireland can be delivered in a way that commands the support of this House, and the European Union, she promised.But Labour boss Jeremy Corbyn asked what hope she had of getting the deal passed after she failed to do so last month.This really does feel like Groundhog Day, he said.Some ministers think that the best way forward is to get Leavers on side to win over Tories and the DUP - rather than reaching out to Labour MPs who want a customs union with the bloc and a softer Brexit.Yesterday key Brexiteer Jacob Rees Mogg suggested hed rather back the deal than risk not leaving altogether.He said this morning: If the backstop could be removed altogether, so could most of the problems be removed.Mrs May also used her speech to slam reports that she could consider reopening the controversial and hard won Good Friday Agreement.The PM stressed: I never never even considered doing so, and neither would I, she said.She also took aim at Jeremy Corbyn for failing to engage in talks to get a Brexit deal done.Last week the Labour boss said he wouldnt talk to her about leaving the EU because shes refused to take No Deal Brexit off the table.Mrs May said she hoped that he would reflect on his decision and said we should all be prepared to work together to get a deal done.He says no more phoney talks - it would be nice to have at least some talks with him! she joked.It would be welcomed by big business - but Brexit voters would be unhappy because it would mean Britain accepting open borders, and following European rules without a say.HOW LIKELY   HARD AS NAILSMost of the Tory Brexiteers who oppose the PMs deal want her toto Brussels and strike a tougher line.But Eurocrats currently insist its impossible to re-open negotiations.HOW LIKELY   REFERENDUM RE-RUNDozens of MPs are hell-bent on forcing Mrs May to hold a second referendum so Britain can stay in the EU.Yet without the support of the Government its unlikely the second vote could become a reality.HOW LIKELY   DEAL OR NO DEAL If Mrs May cannot pass a deal, the legal default is that we will leave the EU without a deal on March .Despite the legal position, the majority of MPs insist they will take any measure necessary to rule out No Deal.HOW LIKELY   MAY TRIUMPHS - EVENTUALLYCabinet ministers remain adamant that a version of Theresa Mays plan will eventually pass the Commons, even after losing last night.They believe sceptical MPs will lose their nerve as Brexit Day approaches - terried of either No Deal or a second referendum.HOW LIKELY   Today Remainers are launching a move to seize control of the Brexit process.Amendments are being discussed today on what should happen next - one plan would be to give backbenchers control, and another would force article  to be extended.The world now knows that Michel Barnier never negotiated in good faith. He reportedly boasted: “I’ll have done my jobthe exit terms are so bad that the British would rather stay.”Yet Remainers want to capitulate anyway: to scrap or “extend” Article , risibly pretending it’s a pragmatic solution instead of what they wanted all along.They would force on us a dangerous second referendum, or some vague pause to avoid No Deal, disgracefully backed by Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd and other Remainer Ministers.The tactics are so undemocratic the Queen might have to block them. That’s right, these MPs could force our monarch, in her rd year, into the worst constitutional crisis for three centuries.Mrs May is now taking the only good option short of No Deal — toto Brussels and renegotiate the backstop.The EU may refuse. Their ciphers in Parliament may even somehow halt  Brexit. That would guarantee only this:An enraged population, electing future Governments more viscerally Eurosceptic and extreme than any Brussels has known.

title: second brexit referendum doctors amendment
story: The Sun can reveal that Tory backbencher Dr Sarah Wollaston is in talks with colleagues from Labour and the SNP to lead the push for a People’s Vote.The formal call will come in the form of an amendment to Theresa May’s ‘Plan B’ motion to be debated next Tuesday, January .If selected by the Speaker it would see MPs vote on a new poll.Ms Wollaston told The Sun: “It’s all about informed consent. You wouldn’t opt for surgeryyou didn’t know the operation you were having. And here, Theresa May is the surgeon.”Other lead signatories are understood to include Tory ex-Minister Dr Philip Lee and Labour’s Dr Paul Williams and Dr Philippa Whitford of the SNP, a breast surgeon.It comes despite People’s Vote insiders admitting privately that only - MPs in the Commons currently back a People’s Vote – nowhere near a majority.A group of Conservative and Labour second referendum backers including Chuka Umunna and Anna Soubry met Theresa May’s de-facto deputy PM David Lidington for confidential talks about a new poll yesterday.They are believed to have warned that a second vote could keep the union together given the strength of the ‘Remain’ vote in Scotland and Northern Ireland.Dr Philip Lee, who quit as Justice Minister last year over Brexit, warned on Monday that both Scotland and Northern Ireland could quit the union unless the PM grants a People’s Vote.He warned the PM’s “Brexit at all costs” strategy would spark a clamour for a second Independence vote in Scotland and a unity poll in Northern Ireland. Both voted ‘Remain’ in .Dr Lee said: “Time is running out to get a deal that works for the whole of the UK. The only way to find a way through the political deadlock is to let the people decide on how the country should proceed, by giving them a Final Say.”  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: annegret kramp karrenbauer irish backstop
story: Unlikely because it does not yet exist and requires a sharp change of attitude on all sides.But in times of crisis, ­anything is possible.Hardline Tory Brexiteers are now prepared to vote for ­Theresa May’s shattered EU Withdrawal Bill — as long as she ditches the wretched Northern Ireland backstop.Meanwhile, Germany is under siege from its political and industrial leaders, who are finally speaking out against a breach in trade and security ties with a vital European ally.Together this makes it ­possible to navigate a way through the thicket of bitterness and rancour which has soured ­politics, ided families and split the British nation.It requires a change of tack from Theresa May — never an easy ask.The PM’s deal is toxic because it hands Northern ­Ireland to Brussels as a ­province of the EU.Cutting out this tumour would win Mrs May the backing of at least  MPs, including Tory Brexiteers and the hardline DUP.Remainers would have ­little choice but to join in, giving Mrs May her majority and scuppering Jeremy ­Corbyn’s demands for a snap election.This might be seen as an impossible dream, not least because the hated backstop was allegedly invented in Downing Street, not Brussels.German negotiators pounced on an easy win.Now Berlin, the ultimate EU power broker, is facing fierce protests from industrialists over the risk to car, aerospace and engineering giantsBritain leaves with No Deal.“A hard Brexit would be disastrous,” says Dieter Kempf, head of Germany’s BDI — the equivalent of our Confederation of British Industry.“It would cause great dficulty for tens of thousands of companies and hundreds of thousands of workers on both sides.”Friday’s touching note from German politicians to The Times newspaper pleads with Britain to stay — or at least leave on friendly terms.But this is no love letter. It is hard-nosed realism.Signicantly, it bears the ­signature of Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer, Angela Merkel’s chosen successor as Germany’s next Chancellor.Her appeal can be seen as a rebuke to Mrs Merkel, who rejected David Cameron’s plea for help to curb immigration, tipping ­Britain towards Brexit.Brits might have chosen dferentlyshe had responded to voters’ dismay not just in Britain but across the EU.She later signed her own political death warrant by flinging open Europe’s borders to a million Syrian migrants.But voters’ resentment towards arrogant EU leaders — recorded by their own Eurostat polling system — long predates immigration.Embattled French President Emmanuel Macron recently admitted he had dared not offer his voters a “Frexit”  ­referendum — because they would leave in a flash.Weeks later, his fears were confirmed as “yellow-vest” anarchists set Paris ablaze.French observers believe the gilets jaunes riots have their origins in another referendum crisis.In , France voted overwhelmingly against the European Constitution — only to see it renamed the Lisbon Treaty and slyly introduced against their express wishes.The European Constitution, like the disastrous euro, was a crucial but unpopular step towards a federal European superstate.Ireland and ­Denmark have also voted down EU moves to ever-closer union.They were told to vote again until they said Yes.Brussels’ arrogant contempt for ordinary voters — dismissed by one French president as “scum” — is what politicians blithely describe as the “democratic deficit”.It sowed the seeds for Brexit. Immigration simply brought it to a head.Germany’s letter to The Times reads like a plea from a deserted lover.“Without your great nation, this continent would not be what it is today — a community defined by freedom and ­prosperity,” writes Germany’s next Chancellor.“Should Britain wish to leave the European Union for good, it will always have friends in Germany and Europe.”This is precisely what British voters hoped for as they ­teetered on the brink of Remain but opted to Leave.They wanted a civilised orce between economic and diplomatic allies.This is still possiblethe border issue can be resolved.If we can persuade the IRA to decommission deadly weapons, surely we can decommission a backstop that nobody wants Theresa May’s rejected deal is not a total failure. Without this problem it could still fly.Germany holds the key.If Mrs Kramp-Karrenbauer means what she said about friendship, now is the time to prove it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit plan b explained amendments
story: NewsBrexit Plan B explained: Amendments to Theresa Mays deal and what they meanBrexits been left a smouldering wreck with barely two months to go. Here are the Plan Bs that are emerging - and how MPs could take back controlShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporterDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN NewsMPs are planning to take control of the process "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBrexit is a smouldering wreck after Theresa Mays deal suffered the worst defeat in House of Commons history. But out of the ashes, a string of radically dferent Plan B options are taking shape - and will wrestle for control in the Commons. The Prime Ministers own Plan B will go head to head with plans from Remain-backing MPs that could delay Brexit or stop it altogether. Labour wants to leave with a customs union, while other Remainers want to force a second EU referendum. Importantly, MPs will hold a vote on some of these options at pm on Tuesday  January - giving Theresa May a mandate toto the EU. Although the vote on her neutral motion isnt binding - what would be called an indicative vote - it will spell the way forward. So what are the biggest amendments that have been proposed so far and what will they do  Heres our rolling guide, which well continue to update as the vote draws near. Theresa Mays Plan B: Rework the Irish backstop and go back to EU in February   Theresa May ed to MPs on Monday  January to outline her own Plan B. She suggested she simply wants to tweak her -page Brexit deal - including a backstop that could trap the UK under EU customs rules - instead of ripping the whole thing up. The PM did not categorically rule out the customs union demanded by Labour - or, crucially, extending the  March date of Brexit. But she tried to rebuff calls for a customs union, a second referendum, ruling out No Deal, or revoking or extending the  March date of Brexit. Mrs May said she will continue with further meetings this week and consult this House on its negotiating mandate before ing to the EU to try and agree a further Plan B. She also offered confidential briefings to MPs on the way forward, guarantees on workers rights, and consultation with parliaments committees. Yet key figures in the EU savaged Mrs Mays Plan B pleas as party politics. And Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn told MPs: The Prime Ministers invitation to talks has been exposed as a PR sham. Contrary to what the Prime Minister just said there was no flexibility, there were no negotiations - nothing hadchanged.  Labour: Give MPs a say on all options - including Labours deal and a second voteJeremy Corbyns party has tabled an amendment which calls for Parliament to have a say on all the options. Two of those should include Labours own Brexit plans which is a Norway plus style agreement and also the option for a second referendum or public voted. Keir Starmer boosted the hopes of Labour supporters of a second referendum at the weekend when he confirmed the party was now at the final stage of its Brexit plan as set out in its September conference. Labour believes its version of Brexit which would include a permanent customs union, relationship with the single market and alignment on rights and standards would command a majority in the House of Commons.  Party sources say the amendment is in line with the partys conference motion. In recent weeks the leadership has insisted that all options remain on the table. But there are a growing number of Labour MPs who want a second vote - while more than % of the partys membership also back another poll. Including the option of a second vote should go some way to keeping those MPs on side.Jeremy Corbyn said: Our amendment will allow MPs to voteon options to end this Brexit deadlock and prevent the chaos of a No Deal. It is time for Labours alternative plan to take centre stage, while keeping all options on the table, including the option of a public vote.   One amendment seeks to suspend Article  - which sets the  March date of Brexit -there is no new deal by the end of February. It is being led by Labour MP Yvette Cooper and Tory MP Nick Boles, both Remain-backers. Ms Cooper, who chairs the Commons Home Affairs Committee, said: I think sheknows that she should rule out no deal in the national interest because it would be so damaging. Shes refusing to do so and I think shes hoping that Parliament will do this for her - that is not leadership. Dominic Grieve: Backbenchers can take control of them agree   A second, more radical amendment, drawn up by former Attorney General Dominic Grieve, would allow something big. MPs would be able to take control of the timetable in the House of Commons - by a minority voting for it. Usually the government has control of the agenda in the Commons, which stops backbenchers going rogue and passing laws. But under Mr Grieves plan,formal business it proposed by at least  of the  MPs - from at least five parties and including  Tories - it would be debated as the first item of Commons business the next day. Downing Street figures branded it a coup. But Mr Grieve said it would enable the Commons to vote on a string of alternatives. These could include a soft Norway-style deal or a second referendum. Alliance of the forces of enlightenmentSupporters of the two plans are understood to have agreed to come together. One MP involved in the discussions told HuffPo: “It looks like the forces of enlightenment will be advancing on several compatible fronts when it comes to amendments.” It is understood the two camps will table compatible motions.These stand a good chance of passing with the combined weight of supporters for both amendments and the support of the Labour leadership.The Labour leader told the Commons on Monday: “We will, as we have said consistently from the beginning, back amendments that seek to rule out the disaster of no deal.” Plus - how the Queen could get dragged in   Theresa May could drag the Queen into a showdown with Parliament,MPs try to cancel or postpone Brexit. Former top government lawyer Sir Stephen Laws said trying to change the law in this way through an amendment, without the Government’s participation, could create a constitutional crisis. In a paper for the Policy Exchange think tank, Sir Stephen said: “It could raise a question whether the Government would be entitled or might feel required to reassert its constitutional veto by advising the Queen not to grant Royal Assent to the Bill. “How should the Monarch react to such advice  The answer is not straightforward and the prospect of it needing to be considered in a real le political crisis is unthinkably awful. “It is a sacred duty of all UK politicians not to involve the Monarch in politics. They have a constitutional responsibility to resolve dficulties between themselves in accordance with the rules, and so as not to call on the ultimate referee.”

title: jeremy corbyn says theresa denial
story: NewsJeremy Corbyn says Theresa May is in deep denial about her Brexit defeatThe Labour leader dismissed the Prime Ministers invitation to talks as a "PR sham"ShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video watch-jeremy-corbyns-response-theresa-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJeremy Corbyn has slammed Theresa Mays plan B saying she was in denial about the scale of her Brexit deal defeat. The Prime Minister was forced toto Parliament to give details of her next step after she lost a vote on the Withdrawal Agreement by  votes - the biggest government defeat ever. Mrs May, who has met with several opposition leaders and senior MPs, has attacked Mr Corbyn for refusing to meet her. But the Labour leader, who has refused to meet while no deal remains a possibility, dismissed the Prime Ministers invitation to talks as a PR sham. He told the Commons: Every opposition party politician came out of those meetings with the same response. Contrary to what the Prime Minister has just said, there was no flexibility there were no negotiations nothing had changed.  The Prime Minister has so far reiterated her desire to seek assurances on the Irish backstop from the EU in order to change the parliamentary arithmetic rather than opting for a softer Brexit which many believe would command a majority in the House of Commons. Mrs May told MPs that two main issues remained with the backstop - the fear that we could be trapped in it permanently and concerns over its potential impact on our UnionNorthern Ireland is treated dferently from the rest of the UK.   The Prime Minister has already spent months seeking concessions from the EU with little success. The EUs assurances set out in a letter from, the European commission president, Jean-Claude Juncker are not legally binding. And today senior figures in the EU have dismissed her pleas as “party politics” warning Mrs May they would not make any compromises unless they could be sure the PM had the numbers to get the deal through parliament.   Today Mr Corbyn said it felt like Groundhog Day as he asked the PM: What makes her think that what she tried to renegotiate in December will succeed in January  Instead he insisted that there was the possibility of a better deal -the PM changed her red lines. And he rejected Mrs Mays assertion that the option for the UK is her deal or no deal. But our EU negotiating partners are clear and I quote: Unanimously the European Council have always said thatthe UK chooses to sht its red lines in the future ... and to go beyond a simple free trade agreement, then the EU will be immediately ready to give a favourable response.

title: no deal brexit could force
story: NewsNo Deal Brexit could force up to  MILLION plane tickets to be cancelledThe IATA, which represents nearly  airlines, warned up to million extra seats are scheduled for  that No Deal Brexit rules might not allowShareCommentsByNeil LancefieldDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsFamily trips this summer could be hit - but we dont know which ones yet "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA No Deal Brexit could force up to MILLION plane tickets to be cancelled, a coalition of  top airlines have warned. The International Air Transport Associationsounded the alarm barely two months before Brexit - warning family trips this summer will be hit. Currently it is not known exactly which tickets could be hit, or how passengers would find outthey are at risk. It only appliesthere is no Brexit deal. The situation arose because in a no deal, there will be no automatic legal basis for flights between the EU and UK after pm on  March . Under a deal struck between the UK and EU last month, basic connectivity will be maintained for a -month periodtheres No Deal. But according to the IATA - which represents  airlines including British Airways - that only means maintaining the number of flights in . [It] does not allow for an increase in flight numbers in  compared to , said an IATA statement.   IATA research estimates that up to  million extra seats are scheduled for  compared to  in order to meet consumer demand. Many of these will be in the peak Summer season when families will be booking holidays. These are at riska ‘no deal’ Brexit occurs. Spokesmen for industry bodies Airlines UK and ABTA played down the risks today, saying the flights quota is still to be finalised. But Labours shadow transport secretary Andy McDonald said: A no-deal Brexit would be a disaster for the UK aviation sector. The Government must immediately reassure the aviation industry that its operating environment will not change after March .Theresa May has to listen to the majority of MPs, as well as members of her own cabinet, and take no-deal off the table.   Today Which  Travel magazine claimed some of the UKs most popular airlines are failing to tell passengers about the threat. Customers should be warned over the possibility of passports becoming invalid andflightsbeing cancelledtheres no deal, the magazine said. The publication issued the alert after studying the websites of easyJet, Thomas Cook Airlines and TUI Airways. Its editor, Rory Boland, told the Press Association: There were no warnings through the booking process on any of those sites about possible cancellations or passport validity. Proposed no-deal guidance from the EU Commission published last month stated thatflightsbetween the UK and EU should continue for  months in the event of a no-deal Brexit, but UK airlines would not be allowed to add new routes or increase frequencies. Airports Council International predicted that -the policy was also applied by the UK to EU airlines - it would ultimately result in the loss of , newflightsand nearly  million airport passengers on the UK-EU market.  Mr Boland said: We think airlines should be more upfront that someflightsmay not be able to depart in the case of a no-deal because it would give potential customers the opportunity to change their plans. That could mean booking a package holiday ... or they may decide theyll still buy the flight but they wont purchase their hotels or car hire until a later date when theyre sure thoseflightsare going to depart. Its giving passengers more information so they can make a better, informed decision about their holidays.  Travellers will need to have at least six months left on their passport from the date of arrival in EU countries in the event of a no-deal Brexit. Mr Boland claimed the Government should be warning people more proactively about the change. He said: The issue will come when everybody suddenly realises as the Easter holidays approach and then theres a mass of applications and the passport office cant handle it. They should be telling people to get those applications in early. What industry associations say about your tickets A spokesman for industry association Airlines UK said: “We have had clarity from both the UK Government and EU that even in the event of a no-deal Brexit air travel will continue. This is in addition to the excellent progress Government has made in concluding bilateral agreements with third countries – including the United States and Canada. It is true there is some detail in the Commission’s no-deal Regulations that we are seeking urgent clarity on – and we have always said we would not support a no-deal outcome – and we remain hopeful that common sense will prevail.” ABTA, the trade body for UK travel agents, said: The European Commission and the UK Government have both said that, even in a no-deal scenario, flights will continue to operate between the UK and the EU. The limitation on flights at the same levels as  is yet to be agreed - it is a proposal that is still to be voted on by Members of the European Parliament who will have to take into account the impact on their own economies. Once further clarity is provided, airlines and travel businesses will wish to review what the impacts may be. In any event, people who book a package holiday have the greatest level of protection as it is down to their travel company to make sure their holiday is provided or offer a full refundthat is not possible. What the government says A Department for Transport spokeswoman said: We are committed to ensuring thatflightsbetween the UK and EU continue, and the European Commission has published a proposal to make sure this happens. This clearly shows that in the event of no deal, both sides are committed to maintaining connectivity. These combined reassurances should allow businesses and passengers to continue to book and travel with confidence.

title: theresa mays brexit groundhog day
story: NewsTheresa Mays Brexit "Groundhog Day" with Plan B almost identical to Plan AThe Prime Minister failed to impress with her latest updates while fuelling speculation that she may delay Brexit and extend Article ShareCommentsByPippa Crerar:,  JAN NewsMay has been warned by Amber Rudd that dozens of MPs are ready to quit next week unless she rules out a no deal Brexit "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May was accused of being stuck in a Brexit “Groundhog Day” after presenting a Plan B almost identical to her rejected Plan A. The Prime Minister told MPs she will press the EU for more concessions on the unpopular backstop. Government insiders said they hope the EU would be spooked by the clock running down to a no-deal scenario. But it was far from clear that the bloc was willing to give enough ground. Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said nothing had changed, despite the PM’s deal being rejected by a record margin last week. He said: “What makes her think what she tried to renegotiate in December will succeed in January  This really does feel like Groundhog Day.”  There was just one major U-turn, with Mrs May saying she was scrapping the pound fee for EU citizens to stay after Brexit, at a cost of poundmillion. Otherwise, the changes were cosmetic. There was little detail on her offer of legal protections for workers’ rights and environmental safeguards and she refused to rule out leaving with no deal as it would not be “honest”. And she suggested a second referendum could “damage social cohesion” by undermining faith in democracy. MPs countered that her approach to Brexit was causing the real ision. Downing Street later denied Mrs May was suggesting there could be riots. The PM also fuelled speculation she plans to delay Brexit Day by refusing to explicitly rule out extending Article . When pressed, she rowed back from a previous commitment to say she was working on a deal “such that we can leave” the bloc.  Welfare Secretary Amber Rudd has warned dozens of ministers are ready to quit next week unless no-deal Brexit is ruled out. The Remainer believes ministers should get a free vote on extending Article . With cross-party talks stalling, the PM’s bid to break the deadlock looked doomed. Senior Tories persuaded her any attempt to compromise with Labour would terminally split their party. Instead, her focus was on offering Brexit bribes to the DUP and hardline MPs over the backstop on the Irish border – and the overtures showed early signs of working. The DUP’s Nigel Dodds praised the PM for “good engagement” and “willingness to try and reach a consensus”. Insiders clung to suggestions from Poland of a five-year time limit on backstop plans. But EU chiefs once again ruled out any changes. Chief negotiator Michel Barnier said Mrs May already had the “best possible” deal. And Irish deputy PM Simon Coveney said a backstop end-date did not represent EU thinking.  Tory Remainers were furious at the PM’s bid to win over Brexiteers and Anna Soubry said: “Here we are with another week of can-kicking – and the truth is, shynothing’s changed.” Sarah Wollaston added: “It’s like last week’s vote never happened. Plan B is Plan A.” Labour MPs were also angry, with Angela Eagle accusing the PM of “playing chicken” with her own shyBrexiteers and the DUP. It came as senior backbenchers began tabling amendments to the Brexit plan to let MPs take control. Labour’s Yvette Cooper was planning a move to delay departure and leading Tory rebel Dominic Grieve plans for MPs to get an “indicative vote” to seeany other deal option could win a majority. But they both need Mr Corbyn’s backing and the Labour leadership is eyeing all proposals with caution. Downing Street said Parliament was unlikely to have a second binding vote on the PM’s deal until February – playing down the shyimportance of next week’s vote. Meanwhile, former Government lawyer Sir Stephen Laws said the PM could drag the Queen into a showdown with ParliamentMPs try to cancel or postpone Brexit – but this could create a constitutional crisis.

title: theresa mays brexit plan b
story: NewsTheresa Mays Brexit plan B roundly rejected by EU leadersMrs May is due to come back to the Commons to spell out her next steps to build a Commons majority for a Brexit dealShareByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video watch-theresa-mays-brexit-statement-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa Mays Brexit plan B was roundly rejected by EU leaders before she even revealed it.The Prime Minister was forced to explain her next step after her Brexit deal was roundly defeated by MPs last week. She told the Commons: It was clear that the governments approach had to change - and it has. And she insisted that meetings with opposition MPs were held in a constructive spirit without pre-conditions.The main announcement was to scrap the pound fee for EU citizens to stay in the UK after Brexit. It comes after the Home Office unveiled new details of its settlement scheme for .million EU citizens living in the UK. But her statement revealed that very little of substance had actually changed.The Prime Minister has been seeking changes to the Irish backstop - a major stumbling block for many MPs.  But Dublin has rejected Downing Streets bid to get concessions on what they see as a key mechanism to ensure an open border on the island of Ireland. And key figures in Europe have dismissed her pleas as “party politics”. She told MPs that two main issues remained with the backstop - the fear that we could be trapped in it permanently and concerns over its potential impact on our UnionNorthern Ireland is treated dferently from the rest of the UK. Mrs May told MPs she would be speaking with parliamentary colleagues, including members of the DUP, to see how the government can meet our obligations to the people of Northern Ireland and Ireland in a way that can command the greatest possible support in the House. The PM said she will then take the conclusions of those discussion back to the EU. But key European figures have already warned Mrs May they would not make any compromises unless they could be sure the PM had the numbers to get the deal through parliament.  On Monday morning Downing Street rejected claims they were considering changes to the  Good Friday Agreement, which brought an end to the Troubles in Northern Ireland, the spokesman said: No. The Prime Minister has been clear on multiple occasions that we are committed to upholding the Good Friday Agreement in all its parts and to delivering a solution that avoids a hard border between Northern Ireland and Ireland. The Prime Minister reiterated that denial saying: I have never even considered doing so – and neither would I.   They also rejected the idea of a bilateral agreement with the Republic of Ireland, which was reportedly being consideredn by Number  as a way to ensure the backstop would not be needed. The PMs spokesman said: Its not something we are looking at. European Parliament vice-president Mairead McGuinness, an MEP for Taoiseach Leo Varadkars Fine Gael party, said a new treaty between the UK and Ireland to replace the backstop was not an option. And theEUs chief negotiator Michel Barnier, who held talks with Irish foreign minister Simon Coveney in Brussels, ruled out the prospect of a separate deal between London and Dublin, telling RTE: As you know ... we are working  as a team, a single team and we negotiate as one. Meanwhile a senior member of Angela Merkels Government, industry minister Peter Altmaier, warned against trying theEUs patience for political reasons. Sympathy, patience and readiness to wait until the UKs position will be claried are of utmost important to avoid the worst, warned Mr Altmaier. They should not be misused for party politics. Large majority wants to exclude hard Brexit - in the interest of the UK and beyond.  While Germany’s Europe minister Michael Roth urged Britain to “think about it again” and stay in the European Union.There was a glimmer of hope for Theresa May as Polands foreign minister Jacek Czaputowicz suggested the deadlock could be broken by setting a five-year time limit on the backstop. He told Polish newspaper Rzeczpospolita: If Ireland asked theEUto amend the agreement with the British on the backstop so that it would apply temporarily - lets say five years - the matter would be solved. It would obviously be less favourable for Ireland than an indefinite backstop, but much more advantageous than no-deal Brexit. Mr Czaputowicz said that London and Dublin were playing chicken over the border and risked a head-on collision in which Ireland stood to lose the most. But theEuropean Commission made clear that Brussels believes the ball is now in Londons court on Brexit. A spokesman told reporters: Dont look for answers from Brussels. Now is the moment for London to speak, not for us.

title: ancient stone circle experts thought
story: NewsAncient stone circle that experts thought was , years old is s replicaThe Leochel-Cushnie stone circle in Aberdeenshire, was thought to date back thousands of years - until a farmer admitted it was a replicsShareCommentsByDouglas BarrieToby Meyjes:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsThe stone circle was thought to date back thousands of years "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA stone circle thought to date back thousands of years has been revealed as a replica built in the s. Archaeologists had hailed the discovery when it was made in Leochel-Cushnie, Aberdeenshire, back in November. However, weeks later they realised their blunder when a local farmer got in touch to say it was a model. Neil Ackerman, historic environment record assistant at Aberdeenshire Council, said: It is obviously disappointing to learn of this development, but it also adds an interesting element to its story.   That it so closely copies a regional monument type shows the local knowledge, appreciation and engagement with the archaeology of the region by the local community. I hope the stones continue to be used and enjoyed - while not ancient, it is still in a fantastic location and makes for a great feature in the landscape. Recumbent stone circles often date back ,-, years and are unique to the north-east of Scotland.   Mr Ackerman added: These types of monument are notoriously dficult to date. For this reason we include any modern replicas of ancient monuments in our records in case they are later misidentied. We always welcome reports of any new, modern reconstructions of ancient monuments, especially those built with the skill of this stone circle and that reference existing monument types.

title: cover up over grenfell style
story: NewsCover up over Grenfell-style cladding that burns at C in just  minutesEXCLUSIVE: Leaked footage handed to the Mirror shows flames shooting up cladding being used on blocks today - in a test which construction firm bosses tried to hide in a non-disclosure agreementShareCommentsByNick Sommerlad:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsFlames leaped up a replica wall and reached temperatures of over C"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHundreds of residents are living at a tower block shycovered in cladding similar to that in the Grenfell disaster. One  failed a fire test in Dubai which should have lasted at least an hour after just  minutes. But families were not told for weeks and the firm which built the X shyEastlands block in Manchester tried to cover up the shock results. Fire safety expert Geoff Wilkinson said: “It is immoral.” With the furore from Grenfell still raging, residents of other tower blocks would expect to be toldtheir buildings have similar shycladding to that in the killer blaze. But families living in one were kept in the dark after  covering their homes failed a fire test within just two months of the inferno – a move branded “immoral” by safety experts. And there was fury as the firm that built the block tried to “cover up” the shocking results by demanding those who carried out the examination signed non-disclosure agreements. Leaked test footage handed to the Mirror showed flames leaping up a replica cladded wall within  minutes and reaching temperatures of more than C –  minutes quicker than the recommended guidelines. The exercise was abandoned after  minutes over safety fears. But residents at the eight-storey X Eastbank block in Manchester were not told about the test until seven week later, when we approached them.  Construction firm Forrest went into shyadministration allegedly without passing the damning test report on to the buildings’ owners. It comes as latest government figures show just five out of  private residential blocks have had their Grenfell-style shycladding, or aluminium composite material, removed.  Building inspector and fire safety expert Geoff Wilkinson said: “If this building failed its test so quickly then that is indicating that there is a risk of external fire spread. The correct and moral thing to do is to remove the cladding and replace it.   “The moral thing is certainly to make the residents aware. It is immoral not to have notied someone there is an issue and that you are putting measures in place. You should be aiming to review the information and putting shymeasures in place within a week or two at the most.” Resident Kostas shyDespotelis, , added: “We have heard nothing about this test. It is worrying.” shy Neighbour Nadia Elzenaty said: “We were not aware of this. I knew a lot of companies were testing this cladding after the fire at Grenfell. It is shydisappointing. X should have someone chasing this up.  “They have a duty of care. There are a lot of tenants in this building. I know it is expensive to fix but you cannot undo the damage of lives lost.” Building regulations require a -minute fire protection barrier between shyapartments in a block. In August , Eastbank was found to have potentially dangerous cladding in a fire brigade shyinspection. But a blaze spread test was not carried out until  months later. Emails seen by the Mirror show the Dubai-based testing firm told Forrest on November : “The assembly fire test was conducted today at our facility.  “Please be informed that the assembly did not meet the acceptable criteria stated in BR  classication standard [for fire performance of external thermal insulation].” Forrest, which was in financial shydficulty, did not pay for the test in full and two weeks later demanded the firm signed a NDA. It wrote: “It’s a v simple shydocument, it merely says that you won’t pass details of the test on to rd parties.” A representative of the testing firm replied: “Why is this requiredForrest is taking the appropriate steps to ensure the safety of the building and its residents  “Signing the NDA blind would then implicate me in any cover up … I am not prepared to allow the people living in that building to be exposed to that kind of risk.” A Forrest employee replied on December  that “unless the NDA is signed we are reluctant to pay it. That’s the position of our main board not me personally”. Nick Sweeney, chief executive officer at X Developments, which owns the property, confirmed his firm knew the test had taken place and had been “made aware” of the shypreliminary findings received by Forrest. He said Forrest had “indicated that the [cladding] assembly did not meet the BR  classication” but had not handed over the test report. Mr Sweeney insisted additional fire safety measures were put in place when the cladding was first identied, including a “waking watch” to alert tenants to evacuate a fire. He said the building was “safe and habitable”. He added: “We’ve been awaiting the final report so we can then consider what works are required to the building.  “X have received a preliminary statement from Forrest but the draft report had not been provided to X prior to you providing the redacted version of the draft report. “We are meeting our professional team to discuss its contents and we will be putting in place such shyremediation strategy as is necessary. “X has delivered letters via email and through a hand delivery through each door informing the residents that the cladding system is being tested and informing them of the enhanced fire safety which has been adopted. “X has agreed an enhanced fire strategy with the fire officer which will remain until the testing has been completed andrequired any shyremedial works undertaken. “X was not aware of the emails between Forrest and [the testing company] nor of the NDA. The NDA is irrelevant to X as we will not be bound by it and will be providing, as we have done to date, full shyinformation we hold to both the fire officer and the government department.” Since being contacted by the Mirror, X has announced it “will be removing the cladding which is affixed to part of the exterior of the building and replacing it with a new system”. The administrators of Forrest would not comment.  Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service said Eastbank was inspected in  and the shycladding was “considered to present a risk of external fire spread”. A spokesman added: “A change to the evacuation strategy was agreed. A number of actions were agreed including the provision of a waking watch in line with guidance from the Government and this was shyimplemented immediately.” The fire service will now “monitor plans to remove and replace the cladding”. X Eastbank, where the  flats cost between pound and pound, a month to rent, was completed in . The Grenfell blaze was started by a faulty fridge freezer at the block in North Kensington, West London, on June , . It spread up the external cladding on the -storey council building, killing  people. Police are considering offences including shycorporate manslaughter. The tragedy sparked a review of building safety. The Ministry for Housing, shyCommunities and Local Government identied  high-rise blocks with ACM [aluminium composite material] cladding, including the  privately-owned ones. Apart from the five private towers that had it removed, figures released last week showed work was underway on another nine. Owners of  blocks said they had “remediation plans in place”, while  “intended” to remediate. But in  buildings shyremediation plans were “unclear”. The Government has spent poundmillion replacing such  on social housing but private owners are accused of lagging behind. Mr Sweeney said X had removed ACM at two blocks but did not reveal whether other X buildings had been identied with the shycladding.

story: NewsDriver told to go down bus lane after accident by police - then FINED £John Rayner was slapped with the fixed penalty notice ater using the bus lane in Swindon, WiltshireShareCommentsByToby Meyjes:,  JAN NewsJohn Rayner has hit out after being slapped with the fine in Swindon "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA driver has hit out after being slapped with a fine for using a bus lane - after being sent down it by police. story: NewsHovis bread, Coco Pops, Maltesers, MMs and Minstrels are all SHRINKINGProducts from household brands such as Hovis and Coco Pops have been among the shrinking staples, along with a couple of very well known chocolate barsShareCommentsByRuki SayidConsumer Editor:,  JAN NewsHovis Best of Both was g and has shrunk to g - and thats not the only well known product to have pared down in size "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShrinkflation has hit bread and cereals harder than other products in recent years, a study reveals. Office for National Statistics research on , items found  were reduced in size while their prices stayed the same between September  and June . And the bread and cereal category had the most cases with  goods – including  breakfast cereals and three loaves. It comes after Hovis shrank the size of its Best of Both from g to g in . Cereal boxes that shrank include Kellogg’s Coco Pops, down from g to g and small packs from g to g. The next two hardest-hit categories were meat and confectionery. The ONS said .% of food goods shrank overall.  The ONS’s Mike Hardie said: “Staples such as bread and cereal are most likely to have seen reductions in size, while consumers may also find some chocolate products are smaller now.” Manufacturers blame drops in size on rising costs of raw materials but the ONS dismissed the idea of Brexit being a factor. Sarah Coles, personal finance analyst at Hargreaves Lansdown, said: “It may simply be that manufacturers have found a way to boost profits under the radar.” Toblerone lovers were livid when Mondelez International cut the number of peaks in , blaming “higher costs for ingredients”. story: NewsMan in nun costume drops severed GOATS HEAD on kerb outside WetherspoonsWARNING - GRAPHIC CONTENT: Saturday night drinkers were disturbed after seeing the severed body part dumped on the pavement in Cheltenham, GloucestershireShareCommentsByPhillip ThompsonBradley Jolly:,  JAN NewsThe incident happened outside The Moon Under Water pub in Cheltenham "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A man dressed as a nun dumped a severed goats head on pavement outside a busy Wetherspoon pub on Saturday night, witnesses claim.Drinkers at The Moon Under Water in Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, were sickened to see the body part strewn on the footpath.One passerby told Gloucestershire Live : It was about .pm Saturday night and the goat head was just on the path outside Wetherspoon, everyone was just acting like normal.We did go past Sunday morning but it was gone. title: mr loophole lawyer reveals prince
story: NewsMr Loophole lawyer reveals why Prince Philip should NOT apologise for car crashNick Freeman, a celebrity lawyer, believes there Duke of Edinburgh has "no requirement" to do anything following his Sandringham accidentShareCommentsByBradley Jolly:,  JAN NewsPrince Philip was seen driving less than  hours after the collision in Norfolk "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince Philip should not apologise for the car crash which left two women injured, according to celebrity lawyer Nick Freeman. Mr Freeman - nicknamed Mr Loophole - said there is there is no requirement for the Duke of Edinburgh to do anything as a criminal investigation has started. He said it would be wrong to apologise while liability or culpability for the crash has not been established. But Mr Freeman added thatthe duke is culpable, he should save taxpayers money and admit his guilt. A criminal investigation is going on so theres no requirement for the Duke of Edinburgh to do anything of provide anything, he said. If he apologises, he could be admitting hes guilty. The dukes Land Rover was in collision with a Kia carrying Emma Fairweather, an unnamed female friend and her a nine-month-old baby near to Sandringham on Thursday.   Ms Fairweather, who broke her wrist on the crash, claims she has not received an apology from the royal family even though she could have been killed. She told the Sunday Mirror: It would mean the world to mePrince Philip said sorry but I have no ideahes sorry at all. What would it have taken for him and the Queen to send me a card and a bunch of flowers   Ms Fairweathers friend also required hospital treatment but her baby was unhurt.Mr Freeman said in most accidents people dont apologise and the duke should keep his own counsel. He added: The duke has three options: wait and see what happens with the investigation, grab the nettle and cough up to what hed done and offer to surrender his licence or he can attempt to get round it.  Buthes guilty he could save the taxpayers tens of thousands of pounds and come out and say, I was at fault. The duke was reportedly overheard telling police at the scene that hed been dazzled by the sun. Mr Freeman previously said the duke could be prosecuted for driving without due care and attentionhe was deemed to have made a mistake. But, he added,the sun was so low that it was in his eyes and made it impossible to see, that could afford him a defence.

title: mums boyfriend crushed toddler 3
story: NewsMums boyfriend crushed toddler, , to death with car seat then ran awayStephen Waterson, , is accused of deliberately forcing his Audi car seat back against three-year-old Alfie Lamb in Croydon, south LondonShareByRebecca Speare-Cole:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsAlfie Lamb was crushed to death "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man accused of fatally crushing his girlfriends three-year-old son by reversing his car seat onto him then ran off to leave others to call for help, a court heard. Mum Adrian Hoare, , placed Alfie Lamb in the back footwell of the car before her boyfriend Stephen Waterson, , deliberately forced his seat back against him, it has been alleged. Alfie died three days later after suffering a cardiac arrest at the home he shared with the couple in Croydon, south London. Waterson and Hoare lied repeatedly after the event and assaulted the two other passengers, in the Audi A, in a bid to cover up their crime, the Old Bailey has heard. The driver, Marcus Richardson, was later assaulted and threatened by Waterson, while Hoare slapped Emilie Williams across the face two weeks after Alfies death, it is claimed.   Mr Richardson - also known as Marcus Lamb - told jurors that Waterson assaulted him two weeks later because he had given police the number plate of the car. He was arrested and questioned about Alfies death on March . Hoares defence barrister, Tana Adkin, asked Mr Richardsonhe blamed Waterson for Alfies death when questioned by police. He replied: No I didnt blame anyone. It was the truth. Jurors heard how paramedics arrived, where the group had got out the car to discover Alfie was unconscious.  They found Mr Richardson giving Alfie CPR while Waterson was nowhere to be seen. Ms Adkin asked whether Waterson had taken Emilies child away to shield her from the scene. Mr Richardson replied: No, Steven ran off and said he could not deal with it all so left me to deal with the ambulance. I did not see Steven take the other child. She was right next to Adrian in Emilies arms. Ms Adkin said: Steven said he took the child up to the flat. Is that right  No, he replied. Prosecutor Duncan Atkinson has told the court Alfie had been fit and well until he got in the Audi on February  last year.  He continued: It follows that during that car journey something happened to Alfie to compress his chest and abdomen so that he went from and active toddler, to a very seriously ill and brain damaged one. The pathologist found that Alfie had died as a result of crush asphyxia. He was squashed by the car seat and suffocated.  This movement was a deliberate action by Waterson who was angered by the noise and fuss that a three and a half year old was making during the journey. Hoare and Waterson, from Croydon, south London, both deny manslaughter. Hoare further denies charges of child cruelty for placing Alfie in the footwell and common assault on Emilie Williams on February . Photos shown to the jury show the footwell of the car after the alleged act.  Waterson further denies intimidating Marcus Lamb, also known as Marcus Richardson, on February . But Hoare and Waterson, have admitted perverting the course by submitting  statements to police. The trial continues.

title: royals were normal theyd asbo
story: NewsopinionIf the Royals were normal theyd all have an ASBO - its time to get these loons off our roadsBritains attitude to Royal car crashes is a bit skew-wfShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsopinion"Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince Philip was in a car crash in which everybody lived. But imagine, for a moment, that one little thing was dferent. Britain has been plunged into mourning by the death of Prince Philip in an horric car accident. In a tragic echo of Princess Dianas death  years ago, it is thought he was not wearing a seatbelt. The Queens strength and stay of  years was killed after he stopped his Land Rover at a junction and was hit by a second vehicle...Or perhaps: A Greek migrant is being hunted by police after crashing into a car carrying a young mum and baby on their way home from a day at the beach. The identity of the man, considered a menace by local road users, is known to officers. It is thought he is married to a local woman, although it is not clear whether he has a legal right to remain in the UK...Or even: Third-in-line to the throne Prince George escaped unscathed after his mum the Duchess of Cambridges car was in a smash on a death-trap road. The woman driver of the other vehicle, who also had a child in the back seat, was breath-tested at the scene... The fact a -year-old was involved in a collision has been used to demand older people resit their driving tests, have their licenses revoked and or be confined to barracks.But as the RAC has quite reasonably pointed out,you revoked the right to drive of those people most likely to have a smash, it would mean young people had the most to lose.So imagine a younger household name was involved: Road safety campaigners demanded footballer Raheem Sterling be jailed after a car smash with a young mum and baby. The controversial midfielder, , was seen getting behind the wheel again just a day later, and our exclusive pictures PROVE he didnt even wear a seatbelt. Young people are a bloody menace on the roads, said Prince Philip, while unveiling a plaque just a mile from the crash scene...But the problem isnt age. The problem is us, and our attitude to royalty. Had Raheem Sterling broken a womans wrist in a car accident, leaving her to get washed and dressed with help of her teenaged son, facing two months off work and possible surgery to rebreak the bones and a letime of that wrist never being quite right again, she wouldnt expect his girlfriend to send flowers. Anyone in that situation would more likely be spitting tacks at the thoughtless arsehole who caused a painful injury to a complicated joint that will require a year of rehabilitation, and would be demanding the insurance company screw him for every last penny.And theyd never expect a personal apology, on the grounds everyone in an accident knows admitting responsibility is something best left to the lawyers. The victim probably wouldnt say it could all be resolved with a phone call from Raheem askingshe was all right, because shes such a big fan of Man City.  And had Prince Philip been just about anyone , the accident might not have happened.The Royals do not know what traffic is, because they are never stuck in it. There are chauffeurs, advanced driving experts, and motorcycle outriders ensuring that they can whizz up the hard shoulder, shoot through the lights and ignore the right of way. When Philip drove his own London taxi to get around the capital, it was so he could AVOID traffic.When they get to wherever theyre going, the gates are open. Someone salutes. People wave. Everyone keeps clear of the wheels, which, of course, are always clean. You will never see a Royal in a car that has fingermarks in the weeks worth of road splatter around the doors. Youll never see their wing mirror with a ding or the wipers on their last swipe. Prince Andrew has been accused of ramming gates with his car at Windsor, and knocking over a police officer at the gates of Buckingham Palace. Princess Anne has been done for speeding at mph, and when Prince Edward was courting Sophie Rhys Jones her neighbours got used to ing into hedges to avoid being mown down as he whizzed along the country lane leading to her family home.They all do it. If that family lived in a Hackney high-rise, theyd all have an ASBO. Perhapsthey had experiences more like the rest of us, then when he pulled up to a T-junction where the sun was dazzling his vision the Duke of Edinburgh would have stopped until he could see there was no traffic.Someone with no experience of traffic, though, would assume the road was empty and just pull out. Andsomeone that daft and entitled was behind the wheel of what was literally an armoured vehicle - regardless of their age - theyd get nicked by police. If they had been ploughing into other cars on a semi-regular basis throughout their driving career, theyd get taken to court.Andthe police actually LIVED with them and spoke to them EVERY DAY, it would happen in minutes. Royals have always, traditionally, been pretty deadly. When they were around, serfs were more likely to be beaten, maids certain to be ravished, and large public protests far more likely to see their leaders run through with a sword. Wars were inevitable with every marital breakdown or romantic refusal.Removing some of their powers was a great idea, but giving them -wheel drive and several tons of moving metal to fling about the countryside at whim probably wasnt. The problem weve got is that we treat the Royals like a dferent species, and are disgusted when they act like one.We want manners and Britishness but we get rude Prussians, with fat fingers and tin ears. Thats why we put up with them we like to think it rubs off.There is a solution, though: remove the gates from their palaces so they cant get out. The ice is melting quicker than experts previously thought, and they say it will likely lead to faster sea level rises, due to the continued, accelerating warming of the Earths atmosphere. The study flies in the face of US President Donald Trump who has repeatedly denied the scientic consensus on climate change. He once claimed the phenomenon was a Chinese hoax intended to hurt American exports. Researchers concerned about global sea level rises have focused on Greenland, where large glaciers stream iceberg-sized chunks of ice into the Atlantic. The chunks float away, eventually melting.   But a new study, published in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, found that the largest sustained ice loss from early  to mid- came from the countrys south-west region, which is mostly devoid of large glaciers. Study lead author Professor Michael Bevis, of The Ohio State University in the States, said: Whatever this was, it couldnt be explained by glaciers, because there arent many there. It had to be the surface mass - the ice was melting inland from the coastline. The melting, which Professor Bevis and his colleagues believe is largely caused by global warming, meaning growing rivers of water are streaming into the ocean during summer.   The key finding from their study is that parts Greenland, which previously had not been considered a serious threat, will likely become a major future contributor to sea level rise. Professor Bevis said: We knew we had one big problem with increasing rates of ice discharge by some large outlet glaciers. But now we recognise a second serious problem: increasingly, large amounts of ice mass are going to leave as meltwater, as rivers that flow into the sea. He said the findings could have serious implications for coastal US cities, including New York and Miami, as well as island nations that are particularly vulnerable to rising sea levels. And he warned there is no turning back.   The only thing we can do is adapt and mitigate further global warming - its too late for there to be no effect, he added. This is going to cause additional sea level rise. We are watching the ice sheet hit a tipping point. Climate scientists and glaciologists have been monitoring the Greenland ice sheet as a whole since  when NASA and Germany joined forces to launch the Gravity Recovery and Climate Experiment, known as GRACE. It involves twin satellites that measure ice loss across Greenland. Data from the satellites showed that between  and , Greenland lost around  gigatons of ice per year, equivalent to an annual sea level rise of . inches.   But the rate of ice loss across the island was far from steady. Professor Bevis team used data from GRACE and from GPS stations scattered around Greenlands coast to identy changes in ice mass. The patterns they found show an alarming trend - by , ice was being lost at nearly four times the rate that prevailed in . And the biggest surprise was that the acceleration was focused in south-west Greenland, a part of the island that previously hadnt been known to be losing ice that rapidly. The scholar’s findings are at complete odd to Trump’s views.   Only on Sunday, the US leader mocked the issue of climate change as eastern America was hit by temperatures as low as -C. He tweeted: “Be careful and try staying in your house. Large parts of the Country are suffering from tremendous amounts of snow and near record-setting cold. “Amazing how big this system is. Wouldn’t be bad to have a little of that good old fashioned Global Warming right now!” Trump was trolled on social media for his lack of understanding of climate change confusing it with simply cold weather.

He was taken off the jet at Goose Bay Airport, a remote military airbase in Newfoundland, Canada, but a mechanical fault meant the plane was unable to take off. It is believed the door had become frozen in the bitter -C conditions as snow fell on the tip of Canada. Some  passengers had to wait for nearly  hours as customs officers were not available overnight.   Temperatures on the plane quickly plummeted to uncomfortable levels, said passenger Sonjay Dutt, a professional wrestleren route to Hong Kong for a show. Crew handed out blankets but the tourists soon became angry, witnesses reported. I think people are so fed up,and so at their wits end, that even the sight of food didnt get everyone up and cheering, Mr Dutt told CBC.   Its been a long, long, long, long day, he later tweeted. United Airlines has since apologised for the delay. But when a relief aircraft finally arrived, passengers had to reach it at another part of the hub by bus.  The new plane had toto Newark - at pm on Sunday. Another angry passenger tweeted: Now we get off the plane and switch to the rescue plane toto Newark.It takes too long to fix the door in this plane.Much of eastern Canada, as well as the US northeast, has been suffering through a glacial cold spell, with heavy snowfalls that have led to scores of flight cancellations. A spokesman for United Airlines apologised, said the flight was originally erted to due to a medical emergency, where medical personnel met the plane and brought the passenger to hospital, but that a mechanical issue prevented it from taking off again.
