title: doug-marr-teachers-may-find-public-dont-support-strikes
story: Additionally, teaching has become progressively more dficult. Challenging pupil behaviour, frequent changes to curriculum and assessment have contributed to stress and workload. Smaller budgets mean doing more with less.The perception that teachers are overworked and underpaid has impacted on recruitment. Nearly all councils have multiple vacancies. Head teacher posts that once would have attracted double digit applications have become hard to fill.Unsurprisingly, teachers have become restless and vocal as they see their salaries fall in real terms. Large demonstrations and near-unanimous rejection of a % increase by Educational Institute of Scotlandmembers were clear signs of the way the wind was blowing. The decision by the EIS Council to ballot members on strike action comes as no surprise.Teachers have a case for a rise but, then again, so have many other public sector workers. Threatening strike action can be a useful bargaining strategy, but teachers and their leaders need to ponder further on its effectiveness and consequences.To paraphrase LP Hartley, the past was a dferent country and indeed, we did do things dferently there. The present social, political and economic climate is very dferent to that of the s and s. Take, for example the number of days lost to strikes. From the early s until the mid-s around  million working days were lost each year. In  the number was ,.That is largely due to the decline in union membership and influence. Additionally, unions have recognised that strike action is rarely effective. Teaching unions have generally bucked the trend and teachers continue to form a largely unionised profession. The relative strength and solidarity of the teaching unions may well be fuelling their apparent readiness to act. Nevertheless, like Marty McFly, teachers are in real danger of being transported back to the future.Very few of those to be balloted would have been involved in the prolonged industrial action of the s and s. That lack of personal experience may well contribute to strong support for strike action. Those of us, however, who lived and worked through those years remember what it was like and the lasting damage it did to the profession and, more importantly, to the youngsters who were in our care.Back then, teachers generally managed to keep parents on side. The strikes and school closures were only part of widespread action by many groups including miners, dockers, transport workers and large swathes of the public sector. It is questionable , in the current climate of austerity and post-Brexit uncertainty, parents will be as supportive. Many of them have suffered reductions in their own spending power and standard of living. They are unlikely to view teachers as a special case especiallyincurring additional expense for child care.Teachers might also wish to consider the moral imperative. Presumably we all entered the profession because of our passionate belief in the le changing potential of education. If so, can reducing young peoplersquos le chances be justied  Surely, very few teachers would argue that these youngsters are mere collateral damage. It was particularly dispiriting to hear one union leader threaten sustained strike action in Government ministersrsquo constituencies. To target particular children because of where they live would be despicable and unacceptable.During the disputes of the s I continued to run a school football team. I recall being berated by a delegation of colleagues, one of whom asked, ldquoWhose side are you on  Up until that time I had never considered that there were sides in education. I naiumlvely believed we were all on the youngstersrsquo side.Hopefully, unions and the Government will recognise that they are both on the youngstersrsquo side. Teachers deserve a rise but it mustnrsquot be our young people who foot the bill. A decent increase spread over two years may be a way out. Sure, it will cost, but not as much as sacricing another generation of young people and their prospects.

title: Iain Macwhirter  MPs must work together to unblock Brexit  or they   ll open the way for authoritarians
story: So, we at least have breathing space, a pause, a moment for reflection. My own wish would be for MPs to seize the moment and vote to revoke Article  altogether. MPs have the power to stop the clock for good, thanks to the good works of legally-minded MPs like the SNPrsquos Joanna Cherry.Staying in the EU is the only sure way to stop the endless arguments about Canada plus, Norway plus, customs union, Irish backstop, regulatory alignment, maximum facilitation and all the rest of the gubbins thatrsquos been occupying our addled brains for the last two-and-a-half years. However, this isnrsquot going to happen.And Irsquod have to agree that it would be undemocratic for MPs to simply reverse the result of the  referendum by revoking A. It may be that Parliament has the power and the constitutional right to do so: referendums are only advisory. But it would leave so much unpleasantness that British politics would be soured for decades. There would have to be a referendum.This is where my unease turns to genuine anxiety. I have a horrible feeling that Labourrsquos Diane Abbott was right on Question Time this week when she said: ldquoBe careful what you wish for. She agrees with Nigel Farage that a repeat referendum is likely to endorse no-deal Brexit, perhaps by an even greater margin than in .Evenit left us with a mirror-image result, with say % Remain against % Leave, that would itself be a disaster because it would have no legitimacy. Yes, some opinion polls say Remain would win a comfortable majority, but they said that last time.The Brexiteers are already field-testing their slogans on social media. The frontrunner is ldquoTell Them Again, which may not be as resonant as ldquoTake Back Control but is still pretty hot. It surfs on the very widespread disgust and alienation that many ordinary people feel about the political elite. It appeals to democratic injustice: how dare the globalists ignore the result of , which David Cameron promised would be for keeps What would Remainrsquos slogan be  Itrsquos likely to be a repeat of the Project Fear line which failed dismally in . ldquoDonrsquot put your childrenrsquos prosperity at risk, perhaps, or ldquoThink Twice Think Jobs. But what many pro-Europeans fail to grasp ndash and this applied to the Unionists in the Scottish independence referendum ndash is that it ISNrsquoT the economy, stupid. Brexit voters donrsquot just make their decisions on the basis of economic rationality, as seen from the CBI and corporate Britain.People are always motivated more by emotion than numbers ndash on what they believe to be morally right. The sense that working-class people have lost control is a very potent mobiliser.As in war ndash and it is remarkable how much Brexit mythology harks back to World War Two ndash people are quite willing to sacrice some comfort for what they believe in.I may think they are mistaken. As with the people who supported Donald Trump because he promised to Make America Great Again, and bring back the jobs, I think Brexit voters have been sold a  prospectus by politicians who do not have the best interests of working people at their hearts.But that isnrsquot really the point. I can well understand the sense of injustice felt by people who have been left behind by global capitalism. They want to kick the system, and the referendum gave them a chance to do it. They need a very strong reason not to kick the metropolitans again. Only Labour can provide that reason, and Jeremy Corbyn has been singularly reluctant to do so.His refusal even to meet Theresa May was irresponsible in this climate. It may have allowed him to avoid coming off the fence, but it looked petty and weak. Corbyn should have gone in guns blazing, demanded that she drop the red lines, and then mobilised Labour for either rejoining the single market or for a referendum.Single market membership has always been the logic of Labourrsquos position, even though Corbyn usually refers to a ldquopermanent customs union. Only by joining the European Economic Area could Labour deliver friction-free trade, and protect environmental standards and workers rights. People say that Norway has blocked the UKrsquos entry to the European Economic Area, but this is not true. The Norwegian PM, Erna Solberg, has repeatedly made clear that Norway would have severe reservations ndashwho wouldnrsquot  ndash but would not block UK membership.This is because the EEA is essentially a Brussels creation. It was set up as a halfway house to membership of the EU back in  when a number of countries were uneasy about joining the political institutions of Europe. The EEA is just the European Single Market under another name.Brussels endorses British membership of the EEA, and this economic arrangement has a number of advantages over Mayrsquos deal. Therersquos no need for an Irish backstop no membership of the CAP and the Common Fisheries Policy no direct jurisdiction of the European Court and it costs less than EU membership. Of course, it does not bring the full benefits of EU membership. Britain would become a ldquorule taker on trade. But the EEA does not preclude future membership of the European Union. Norway, or any other member of the EEA, can opt for full membership at any time. And unlike the backstop, countries can leave the EEA after one year.Membership of the single market also means accepting freedom of movement, which is why it may well be rejected by Parliament. But it is the only option that has a snowballrsquos chance of getting a majority,Labour were to seriously support it. ldquoNorway plus, as itrsquos called, has more support than a repeat referendum. Fewer than  Labour MPs have called for a Peoples Vote, and only  Conservatives. The SNP has decided to throw its lot in with a repeat referendum, despite having argued convincingly for the single market for the last two years. But that isnrsquot enough.To repeat. Were it left to me, I would revoke Article  tomorrow. I just want this madness to stop. But given the metrics in Parliament, we have to look at the least worst options, as the Labour-supporting commentator Owen Jones put it last week. Mayrsquos deal is dead. MPs owe it to the country, and to themselves, to find some compromise that works. Perhaps that can only be achieved with a referendum. ButMPs fail this week, they risk destroying respect for parliamentary democracy, and opening the way for a more authoritarian form of political leadership.

title: alex-salmond-piles-pressure-on-nicola-sturgeon-over-indyref2
story: Mr Salmond said the Westminster crisis over Brexit meant there was ldquonot likely to be a better time to force the issue.He told the Sunday National: ldquoNicola should be concentrating all her energies on the independence agenda when we will never have better circumstances.ldquoAs far as I am concerned Westminsterrsquos Brexit dficulty should be Scotlandrsquos opportunity.ldquoRight now, the Westminster political establishment is at its weakest point in my letime while the national movement is in good heart.ldquoThere is not likely to be a better time to force the issue.The Scottish Tories said the war between the Yes movements two biggest beasts was getting worse by the day, and urged Ms Sturgeon "to put Alex Salmond back in his box".Mr Salmondrsquos comments come amid open ision in the Yes movement over the timing of Indyref.Ms Sturgeon has said she will give an update on timing in ldquoa matter of weeks, but appears to be playing a long game, focusing for now on a Peoplersquos Vote over Brexit.However an increasingly strident Mr Salmond - buoyed by his legal win against the Scottish Government over its botched misconduct probe into him - is pushing for immediate action.The split between the past and present first ministers has led to a bitter briefing war.Ms Sturgeonrsquos office has accused the ldquoother side of "smears" and waging a ldquovendetta".Mr Salmond blamed the ldquounionist press for ldquoprovoking a response, but admitted he had told his own spinners and proxies to stop getting involved.He said: ldquoIt takes two to tango and Irsquom just not playing this game. I have told my team that we are not getting involved. This lsquouncivil warrsquo stops now.However Ms Salmondrsquos comments only highlighted the disagreements over Indyref.The Sunday Times reported Ms Sturgeon has been warned by senior colleagues not to rush into another independence referendum.Pete Wishart, the SNPrsquos longest serving MP, told the paper: ldquoWe should have a second referendum when we can win it. We are already making progress towards that, with Brexit as the catalyst, but it will be dficult to secure the conditions to make a referendum happen before the next Scottish election.Ms Salmondrsquos former special adviser Alex Bell also said the SNP needed to create a positive case for independence, not try to achieve it on the back of other peoplersquos mistakes.He said: ldquoThe SNP and Yes have to stop seeing independence as a sneaky prize to be won when everyone  is messing up and instead base their campaign on the reality of what Scotland can achieve through an honest understanding of the world.Scottish Secretary David Mundell has written to Theresa May to urge her to maintain her refusal to grant Holyrood powers for a second independence referendum.Referring to the the growing pressure on the SNP leader, he said: ldquoIt is unlikely that elements of her party will continue to accept further delays, especiallyit becomes apparent that there will not be a second European Union referendum.Former SNP deputy leader Jim Sillars said: ldquoThere is no appetite for a second independence referendum, there is no national Yes organisation in place - a prerequisite to success as many Yes activists and voters are not SNP - nio policy work has been done, and thus we are not in a position to deploy the new policies in that post-Brexit new paradigm that will be needed to convince No voters to vote Yes next time.Robin McAlpine, of the Common Weal think tank, told the Sunday National: ldquoFor a number of reasons, we can no longer realistically get a referendum before .Scottish Conservative chief whip Maurice Golden said:"The war between the SNPs two biggest egos is intensying by the day."When theyre not feuding over the complaints against Alex Salmonds conduct, theyre fighting about the timing of another independence referendum."By taking the threat of another vote off the table, Nicola Sturgeon would reassure the Scottish population who dont want a re-run, and put Alex Salmond back in his box."Scottish Liberal Democrat Leader Willie Rennie said: ldquoThe First Minister must not inflict another isive referendum on our country in a desperate bid to heal the isions in the SNP.ldquoThatrsquos exactly what the Conservatives did with Europe and look where that got us. The SNP should ditch their plans for another referendum and instead work with genuine pro Europeans to avoid the chaos of Brexit.ldquoBreaking up is hard to do - the SNP at least should see that from Brexit. First Minister, put our country before your party.A Scottish Labour source added:"The last thing Scotland needs is more instability and chaos of yet another independence referendum, what our communities need are Labour governments here and in Westminster to end austerity."

title: scotland-needs-to-do-more-to-make-lbtq-staff-feel-welcome-at-work-says-equality-charity
story: Recent high-profile ad campaigns confronting homophobic and transphobic hate by the Scottish government and Police Scotland have been feted worldwide, and the country is set to make history when it becomes the first to embed the teaching of lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and intersexrights in the school curriculum.However, a recent survey of the top  LBTQ employers in the UK shows we may be less tolerant than we think.Only five Scottish employers featured in the top , out of a total of  organisations and companies across dferent sectors which vyed for a coveted spot on the list, and was compiled by equality charity Stonewall.Moreover, the Scottish employers featured did not even make the top ten. Skills Development Scotland, the Golden Jubilee Foundation, the Crown Office  Procurator Fiscal Service, the Scottish Government and the City of Glasgow College were ranked at numbers , , ,  and  respectively.However, Skills Development Scotland were given a special commendation for going above and beyond to make trans staff feel accepted.The survey comes as trans people continue to face worrying levels of abuse in both their private lives and in the public sphere. One in eight trans employeeshave been physically attacked by a colleague or customer in the last year.Moreover, research released by Stonewall last year that showed more than a third of LGBT staffhave hidden they are LGBT at work and almost one in five LGBT employeeshave been the target of negative comments from colleagues because of their identity.Darren Towers, Stonewallrsquos executive director, said:"Scotland has made impressive strides when it comes to driving LGBT equality forward in society. Wersquore very proud of the employers featured in the Top . We know from our recent research that one in eight lesbian, gay and bi staff in Scotlandare not open with anyone at work about their sexual orientation, while nearly one in five trans employeesarenrsquot open about their gender identity for fear of discrimination. So, whilst employers based or working in Scotland have achieved much, therersquos more for us all to do. Every employer has the power and the opportunity to make changes to improve the situation for LGBT staff."John Wilkes, Equality and Human Rights Commission head of Scotland, said: "Scotland takes pride from the fact we are a tolerant and inclusive country. Itrsquos good to see the businesses and public bodies, including the Scottish Government, helping to lead the way on LGBT rights but wersquod really like to see more Scottish employers on this list and urge them to learn from the success of others. Everyone in Scotland has the right to a working environment that helps them reach their full potential.Nationally, law firm Pinsent Masons - which has three offices in Scotland - is said to be the best lesbian, gay, bi and transemployer in the UK because it demonstrated a range of inclusive policies and practices for lesbian, gay and bi staff, and featured specic trans-inclusive staff training to create a welcoming environment for trans colleagues, clients and visitors.Other national organisations which have offices in Scotland such as security service MI, Lloyds Banking Group and Barclays also featured in the top .Universities featured prominently in this years list with nearly one-fth of the top  ranked employers in the higher education sectorStonewall collected more than , anonymous responses from employees on their experience of the UKrsquos workplace culture and ersity for the survey.

title: mark-smith-for-all-our-sakes-four-facts-about-the-snp-that-we-can-all-hopefully-agree-on
story: :Alex Salmond takes swipe at SNP leadership over IndyrefSo, in the spirit of trying to encourage more facts in a post-fact world, could I offer you four which I think we can rely on  I realise, of course, that some people will immediately look at my list and say theyrsquore not facts at all, theyrsquore opinion, but all I can say is that this is a genuine effort to distil the last few days of argument over the SNP, Nicola Sturgeon and the Alex Salmond investigation into four areas where I think most of us could find agreement. Here goes.The first one is this: the Salmond investigation is unlikely to change many minds on independence, which is where Walter Macfarlane comes in. Walter, I should explain, has been dead for  years but I only came across him for the first time a few days ago while I was reading the journals of the great Scottish diarist James Boswell. Boswell writes about meeting Macfarlane in the entry for Sunday  November  and describes him as a man who was ldquokeenly interested in the reigning contests between Scots  English.:Poll suggests SNPs credibility damaged by Alex Salmond allegationsldquoHe talked much against the Union, writes Boswell of his new friend. ldquoHe said we were perfect underlings, that our riches were carried out of the country, that no town but Glasgow had any advantage of trade by it, and that many others were hurt by it.Why am I bringing this up now  Mainly because it demonstrates something thatrsquos often forgotten, which is that unhappiness with the Union and support for independence is not a modern phenomenon, and itrsquos not all about the SNP either. As you can see from Boswellrsquos diary, Macfarlane was complaining about the Union just  years or so after the Act of Parliament that brought it about and  years before the SNP was even thought of. Which is the important point: independence has always been a strand of Scottish opinion and, seen in that long historical context, the travails of Nicola Sturgeonare unlikely to greatly change that one way or the other.The second fact is this: the Salmond investigation has emphasised that there are serious isions in the SNP. Some nationalists appear to be offended by this idea and deny there is any ision at all but the briefings of Salmond supporters against Sturgeon and vice versa speak for themselves. In fact, even as he made an apparent appeal to end the acrimony at the weekend, Alex Salmond couldnrsquot resist turning his handshake into a punch. He said he had ordered his team not to become involved in any more exchanges before criticising Sturgeon for not concentrating on independence. There may be some in the SNP who insist this doesnrsquot represent ision but then Baghdad Bob insisted there were no American troops in Iraq to the sound of American troops in Iraq.The third fact leads straight on from the ision in the SNP but is about nationalism more generally and itrsquos this: levels of support for both sides of the independence debate have not shted.In some ways, this third fact is the most surprising of all because, on the face of it, the circumstances are in place for a breakthrough on either side. For the opposition parties at Holyrood, therersquos the Salmond investigation and its implications for Sturgeon and yet support for the SNP has not changed, and for the nationalists, therersquos the crisis of Brexit and yet the polls continue to show  per cent of Scots want to remain in the UK. The nationalists may talk about a ldquosurge and the unionists may revel in the SNPrsquos crisis, but the polls havenrsquot changed. Thatrsquos a fact.Which leads us to the fourth, final, and perhaps most controversial fact: a second referendum on Scottish independence before  is less likely than it was two years ago. Partly, this is because of those polls againbut itrsquos also because of the logistics and timing. The reality now is that we may not know ndash even by  ndash what Brexit is going to look like and Sturgeon herself has said there will be no announcement until the fog has cleared. Then therersquos the clincher: there is no prospect of a Section  order giving permission for a referendum from the Conservative Government. Thatrsquos a fact many of those in the independence movement simply pretend does not exist.:Calls for public inquiry into "unlawful" handling of sexual misconduct complaints against Alex SalmondThe effect of all of these facts, as Irsquove confidently called them, is another matter entirely and depends on how much the politicians resist them. In the wake of the Salmond investigation, itrsquos certainly hard to imagine the SNP fighting the  election campaign with any of the confidence it had in  and , and even in , but then again therersquos every chance Nicola Sturgeon will stick to the grid and announce a referendum before  in the hope that its rejection by the UK Government will increase support for her position.Should that happen, I have honestly no ideathe strategy would work ndash the facts donrsquot stretch that far ndash but maybe now would be a good time toto the diaries of James Boswell for some insight from the past.Writing on  December , just a few days after his meeting with Walter Macfarlane, Boswell got to thinking about the upheavals caused by unrest and war. He did not much care for the quarrels of Mankind when ided into particular states and nations, he wrote, but he could see that they depended not on facts but on the frailties of humans. ldquoI can see that Great People, those who manage the fates of Kingdoms, he said, ldquoare just such beings as myself.

title: theresa-may-set-to-reveal-plan-to-ditch-irish-backstop-in-bid-to-win-over-brexit-deal-critics
story: Last week, the Prime Minister said she would focus on cross-party talksto get a withdrawal agreement accepted by Parliament.But it is understood she is now seeking to win approval from her own benches and show the EU that MPs could back a deal without a backstop in the hope of encouraging Brussels to soften its position.The backstop is the "insurance policy" in the withdrawal deal, intended to ensure there is no hard border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic after the UK leaves the EU.Mrs Mays initial withdrawal deal was rejected by a majority of  MPs in a historic defeat earlier this month.If Parliament doesnt approve a withdrawal agreement, the UK is due to leave the EU on  March without a deal or transition period.The prime minister will address the Commons on Monday afternoon, setting out how she intends to proceed with the Brexit withdrawal agreement.She will also table a "neutral" motion, simply saying that the Commons has considered her statement, which will be debated and voted upon on January .This motion is expected to attract amendments from groups of backbenchers seeking more of a say in the process.Read more: Brexit - What might happen nextTwo groups of MPs are expected to table bills which could take a no-deal Brexit off the table, and potentially suspend Article  - which allows the UK to leave the EU.One of the groups -which includes Labours Yvette Cooper, Conservative Nicky Morgan, and Liberal Democrat MP Norman Lamb - wants the UK to extend negotiations with the EU beyond  March,MPs do not approve a withdrawal agreement by  February.There was anger among pro-Leave MPs at moves to enable backbenchers to take control of the Commons business from the Government - in breach of normal conventions - through a series of amendments to the neutral motion.One group including senior Labour MP Yvette Cooper and Tory former minister Nick Boles is seeking to give time for a bill to suspend the Article  withdrawal processthere is no new deal with Brussels by the end of February.Another more radical amendment drawn up by former attorney general Dominic Grieve would allow a motion by a minority of  MPs - from at least five parties and including  Tories - to be debated as the first item of Commons business the next day.Read more:Ian Blackford urges PM to lsquofundamentallyrsquo change position on BrexitMr Grieve said it would enable the Commons to stage a series of "indicative votes" on the ious alternatives, such as a "soft" Norway-style deal or a second referendum to establish which could command a majority.He denied claims he was seeking to prevent Britain leaving the EU after International Trade Secretary Liam Fox accused pro-Remain MPs of trying to "hijack" the  referendum vote.Mrs May is expected to use her statement to explain how she intends to proceed in the run up to the vote on January , rather than setting out a detailed "plan B".But Ian Blackford blasted the reported plans, tweeting on Monday: "The threat to reopen the Good Friday agreement is beneath contempt from a Prime Minister who I did not think could plumb such depths. To play with the relative peace in Northern Ireland is not on. The rest of us have to state this is a complete no go area. This PM has to go."

title: loch-fleet-freezes-over-as-temperatures-drop-across-scotland
story: Yet, as the North Sea froze as it fed into Loch Fleet in Sutherland between Dornoch and Golspie, where the Met Office recorded temperatures of -degCand -degCon respective nights, it betrayed how cold Scotland is right now.To chill the spirits further this Blue Monday, forecasters warn worse is very much on the way.:Cold weather lsquohere to stayrsquo with disruptive snow possible, say forecastersTonightrsquos evening rush hour is already forecast to be a miserable affair, with gales in the north, snow on high ground and torrential rain in the Central Belt.Transport networks, particularly west coast ferries, are likely to be disrupted.Luke Miall, of the Met Office, said: ldquoItrsquos Blue Monday and the temperature maps look pretty blue, too. It has been cold the last few nights and looks to be getting even colder by the middle of this week.ldquoIn higher spots, where snow is lying, we might see -degCor even -degCon Wednesday night.The coldest night the UK has seen so far this winter was the -.degCat Braemar, Aberdeeshire, last week.The term ldquoBlue Monday was dreamed up by Dr Clf Arnall, a psychologist formerly of Cardf University, to portray the most depressing day of the year.He says the third Monday in January is the day when people lose the last glow of the festive period, break New Year resolutions, realise they have put on weight and look out to miserable weatherconditions.Mr Miall added: ldquoThe accompanying frontal system will bring heavy rain and hill snow above  metres .ldquoAnyone driving home after work in the Central Belt will face dficult conditions, with a lot of rain on the ground. There could be blizzards in the north.A forecast of winds gusting to mph has placed many west coast ferry services on notice for delay or cancellation today.Caledonian MacBrayne said the weather could affect sailings from Oban to Coll and Tiree, Fionnphort to Iona, Ullapool to Stornoway, and between Uig, Skye, and Lochmaddy, North Uist.The coldest spell for six years is likely to see  gritters and  snowploughs deployed as the expected five-week big chill from Europe brings an estimated  inches of snow to some areas of Scotland, likely beginning next week.The RAC predicts there will be up to , extra vehicle breakdowns daily across all UK road service providers.Its spokesman Simon Williams said ldquoThis is the biggest test of the countryrsquos winter resilience since the Beast from the East [last February March].ldquoAlmost all gritters will be out. Motorists should pack a blanket, shovel and phone battery charger in case they are needed.Some  gritters in Scotland are digging into a , tonne salt mountain.Network Rail will use  de-icing trains around the UK.

title: one-fifth-of-scottish-businesses-not-ready-for-brexit
story: The Scottish Government-commissioned EY report found Brexit-related uncertainty was a ldquomajor concern for firms north of the Border, affecting competitiveness, profitability and even viability.Companies cited the risk of higher consumer prices ndash particularlyfor food, drink and energy ndashfrom short-term currency risks and from tarfs and border disruptions.:Theresa May set to reveal plan to ditch Irish backstop in bid to win over Brexit deal criticsTwo-thirds of the  participants, which included trade bodies as well as businesses across nine sectors, were not confident the UK would secure a Brexit deal by March.Although  per cent of businesses said they had taken steps to prepare for Brexit, % did ldquonot feel ready for Brexit at all, and only % said they felt fully ready for Brexit.Businesses also raised concerns that Brexit would reduce access to talent at all wage and skill levels,with the food and drink, financial services, le sciences and creative sectors particularly affected.The report states: ldquoTarfs and non-tarf barriers will clearly make it harder for Scottish businesses to trade with the EU, and will likely reduce the volume of trade.ldquoImpacts are likely to be felt quickly, although longer term there may be opportunities to explore alternative international markets and rebuild domestic supply chains.Finance Secretary Derek Mackay said it showed why the UK Government should take a no-deal Brexit off the table immediately.He said: ldquoIt captures the authentic voice of Scottish business and offers further evidence of the severe and disproportionate impacts that a no-deal outcome would have.ldquoMany businesses highlighted the risks to their competitiveness and profitability, some were worried about future viability and a number are already reporting negative impacts on investment, the costs associated with planning for Brexit and recruitment of staff.:Mark Smith: For all our sakes, four facts about the SNP that we can allagree onSeparately, a UK-wide survey of  business leaders by the Institute of Directorsfound a Peoplersquos Vote was the most popular way out of the current impasse.he poll found % of IoD members backeda second referendum, while % would prefer a revised version of Theresa Mayrsquos withdrawal deal, and just % backed a No Deal Brexit.The Federation of Small Businesses also reported almost three in five small firms felt the political uncertainty had become a signicant barrier to growth. It said UK small business confidence had fallen to the lowest level since , particularly in accommodation and food services, retail and manufacturing.FSB national chairman Mike Cherry said: ldquoHow have politicians allowed it to come to this  ldquoTwo and half years on from the Brexit vote and small businesses are looking ahead to Brexit day with no idea of what environment they will be faced with in less than ten weeksrsquo time.

title: ken-smiths-diary-on-the-ledge-burning-remark
story: GREAT to see BBC Scotland showing the Auchinleck Talbot v Ayr United cup game on the telly, especially as Auchinleck won. It was also interesting to note as the cameras panned around the compact stadium that the ground is in the middle of a housing scheme. As one Ayrshire reader noted: "Only in Auchinleck would the folk be watching the game from their house windows when the game is on the telly."Burning remarkAS Burns Night approaches we hear from Dundee where former MP Jim McGovern gave the Toast to the Lassies at the local Labour Party Burns Supper. His we Norma gave the reply with the great opening line: "When I realised I was speaking right after Jim, I thought, Jim is used to public speaking, hell be a hard act to follow. Thankfully I was wrong!"And our story about the Rev James Currie being known as The Thief of Bad Gags for copying down lines from other Burns Supper speakers reminds Ian Young: "As an inveterate note taker myself, when attending dinners, of other speakers jokes for my later use, I have long been aware of the possible admonition from the top table speaker of, Am I speaking slowly enough for you . To fend this off, I have developed my own ready response of, Oh, Im not writing them down, Im ticking them off."Driving atWHATS the latest on Brexit, dare we ask. TV reporter Matt Frei reveals: "Overheard in Berlin bakery, Brexit is like a -year-old Royal behind the wheel. You know its a bad idea, but are too polite to stop it."And as someone  commented: "Theresa May - the kind of negotiator to come out of DFS with a full priced sofa."Hard to swallowOUR hospital stories remind Eric MacDonald: "A friend unfortunately in hospital on New Years Day was visited by his daughter who brought him in a pre-mixed gin and tonic to celebrate. The mixture was poured into a clear plastic cup and he was enjoying the tipple. Half way though his drink a nurse came into the room and spotted the cup. She picked it up and poured the contents down the sink, saying, Irsquoll just get you some fresh cold water Silence!"Sining feelingTHE Herald on Sunday feature about how invigorating it is to swim in cold water reminds us of the yarn: "My husband lost two stones swimming last month," said the woman in the wine bar. "I knew I should have tied them around his neck better."Bin thereRAISING children, continued. A reader passes on a comment from a female friend: "I told my children that occasionally I need some Me time when they should leave me alone. I didnt realise they would make it happen when the bins need taken out, when the table needs set, and when the shopping has to be brought in from the car."And as writer Stephanie Ortiz remarked the other day: "Two hours ago I asked one of my teens to move wet laundry into the dryer. I now see that I shouldrsquove specied that the dryer should be turned on. On the bright side, looks like one less college tuition to afford."Rings a bellAND a female reader tells us: "Its pretty obvious that car designers are all men. Why isnt there a button on the dashboard you can press for Its only some shopping bags for Gods sake when the fasten seatbelt pinger goes off."Light bulb momentMORE on growing old, as Ronnie McLean tells us: "Its a bit upsetting that the new LED light bulbs I bought have, on paper, a better le-expectancy than my demographic profile."

title: ulva-hundreds-apply-for-a-new-life-on-remote-scottish-island
story: An application processwas established to try and attract those with appropriate skills, such as building, tourism and forestry to the remote island that was subject of a community buyout last year.Once home to over  people in the th century, the island currently has just two properties and five people living there.New ambitious plans will see the population more than double in the next few years with at least six properties added.Last year, a pound.mbid from the Scottish Land Fund and the Macquarie Group in line with a crowdfunding campaign saw the community buy the island.:Islanders halt pound.m Ulva sale with community buyout planThe long term aim is to have  people living on the island.Colin Morrison, thechairman of the North West Mull Community Woodland Company, the body representing residents told the i: ldquoTherersquos been a lot of interest because I think it has captured the imagination.ldquoA lot of people are now aware of what we are trying to do ndash I think we have done reasonably well in getting the word out.ldquoThere is a paucity of housing in rural areas, so therersquos lots of interest because therersquos not much  that comes up.ldquoWe need to be able to show the level of interest before we can apply to renovate and build more houses.ldquoThis survey is about showing and quantying the demand and the interest.:Laird questions SNP government tactics during Ulva buyoutRenovation work on the piers is getting underway shortly, and discussions are ongoing about establishing new woodlands.With applications to live on the island open until the end of January, Mr Morrison is expecting more applications.He said:ldquoSome of the properties we will be renovating will lend themselves to new families.ldquoBut our aim is to get a good balance of people on the island. ldquoIn the next couple of years we hope to get into double figures fairly quickly.ldquoIn the longer, longer run we are looking at up to  people living on the island.ldquoA local primary school already exists just across the water on the mainland at Ulva Ferry.ldquoThe secondary school is in Tobermory on Mull and children will be transported there from the island.

title: snp-mp-angus-macneil-calls-for-party-to-change-strategy-and-for-indyref2-to-come-to-fore
story: In a further sign of ision in the Yes movement over Indyref, Angus MacNeil said another referendum on Europe wasnrsquot wanted, so the independence vote should be to the ldquofore.ldquoChange in media strategy now  the Western Isles MP tweeted at his own party.:Herald poll: Scotland should have independence referendum after BrexitReacting to a Sky News poll showing % support for a Peoplersquos Vote and % opposition, Mr MacNeil tweeted: ldquoOh well @theSNP you tried but #EuroRef not wanted... So now it is the referendum with the mandate #Indyref to come to fore... Change in media strategy now "In another tweet, he described a Peoplersquos Vote - which is backed by Ms Sturgeon and SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford - as ldquoan unwanted, mandateless exercise.Oh well @theSNP you tried but #EuroRef not wanted ... So now it is the referendum with the mandate #Indyref to come to fore... Change in media strategy now  https:t.co VZwFDmygMr MacNeil, who has represented theMr MacNeil, an MP since , also promoted a link to an article by former perjurer and MSP Tommy Sheridan, which called for independence ldquonow, no s, not buts, no maybes.The condemnation of the First Ministerrsquos approach comes after a weekend intervention by Alex Salmond, who told his successor to hurry up with independence.The former First Minister said: ldquoNicola should be concentrating all her energies on the independence agenda when we will never have better circumstance.ldquoAs far as I am concerned Westminsterrsquos Brexit dficulty should be Scotlandrsquos opportunity.ldquoRight now, the Westminster political establishment is at its weakest point in my letime while the national movement is in good heart.ldquoThere is not likely to be a better time to force the issue.:SNP MP tells Nicola Sturgeon people have waited long enough for IndyrefFormer SNP MP George Kerevan also called for a second independence referendum on Monday, warning ldquoScotland will not forgive usthe Brexit crisis was not seized upon.Advocating ldquopushing the independence red button now, he admitted: ldquoI think the majority of the Yes movement is in agony over whatthe best thing to do.Mr Kerevan, a former Marxist who was MP for East Lothian from  to , saidthe UK government continued to deny Holyrood the power for a referendum ldquothen we must march in the streets to demand our democratic rights. When was democracy won without a struggle Writing in the National, he said: ldquoNothing can or will drop in our lap overnight.ldquoBut thatrsquos not the same as waiting for change to come about slowly.ldquoThere are decades where nothing happens politically, and weeks where decades of progress can occur. We are living at such a moment.ldquoLetrsquos not fumble our chance. Scotland will not forgive us.Mr Kerevan also sniped at Andrew Wilson, the author of the SNPrsquos cautious new economic blueprint for independence, for his wary approach to a new plebiscite.The SNP won the  Scottish Parliament elections on a manesto that explicitly stated there should be a fresh vote on independencethere was a material change in circumstances from the  referendum - making clear this should be the caseScotland was removed from the EU against its peoples wishes.Ms Sturgeon has saidshe will make her views known on the possible timing of a second independence referendum in a "matter of weeks".However, the First Minister is facing questions in the wake of Mr Salmonds legal victory against the Scottish Government, after the Court of Session in Edinburgh ruled its handling of sexual misconduct allegations against the former SNP leader to be "unlawful".The allegations - which are strenuously denied by Mr Salmond - have caused a split within the party which he led for  years, with his supporters amplying grassroots calls for Indyref soon.An SNP spokesman said: "The SNP believes that independence for Scotland is the best way to protect our interests and to see our democratic decisions respected."Brexit has brought the failure of the current UK system into sharp focus, with Westminsters shambolic handling of the current situation making the case for independence stronger by the day."Of course, in  Scotland voted by a clear majority to stay in the EU. We continue to fight to protect that status and for the jobs, economic benefits and better living standards that being part of the EU gives us. If theres to be another vote which allow us to remain in Europe, then we should back that opportunity."

title: ancient-scottish-stone-circle-actually-built-in-1990s
story: Archaeologists in Leochel-Cushnie, Aberdeenshire, were thrilled when they were told of a construction discovered on a farm, which appeared to match the features of lsquorecumbent stone circlesrsquo, unique to the north east of Scotland.An excited landowner tipped off historians about the find in December, and research began which estimated it had been built between , and , years ago.Read more:Newly identied stone circle on Aberdeenshire farmBut hopes of a major discovery were dashed, when the farmer who formerly owned the land came forward to reveal the monument was a replica, built in the mid-s.Recumbent stone circles have a large horizontal stone flanked by two upright ones, usually situated between the south-east to south-west of the circle.Some unusual features were noted during the initial investigation, including the circlersquos small diameter, proportionately small stones and lack of an obvious associated cairn or kerb stones.But it was deemed to be an lsquoauthenticrsquo stone circle, by Adam Welfare of Historic Environment Scotland and Aberdeenshire Councilrsquos Archaeology Service.The stone circles are well known and spread throughout the north east of Scotland, but it is rare to find a previously unrecorded one.Neil Ackerman, historic environment record assistant at Aberdeenshire Council, said: ldquoIt is obviously disappointing to learn of this development, but it also adds an interesting element to its story.ldquoThat it so closely copies a regional monument type shows the local knowledge, appreciation and engagement with the archaeology of the region by the local community.ldquoI hope the stones continue to be used and enjoyed ndash while not ancient it is still in a fantastic location and makes for a great feature in the landscape.ldquoThese types of monument are notoriously dficult to date.ldquoFor this reason we include any modern replicas of ancient monuments in our records in case they are later misidentied.ldquoWe always welcome reports of any new, modern reconstructions of ancient monuments, especially those built with the skill of this stone circle and that reference existing monument types.

title: scottish-government-facing-calls-for-ban-on-electric-shock-collars
story: Scottish Environment Secretary Roseanna Cunningham announced last year she would take steps to effectively and "promptly ban" the use of the collars in Scotland and guidance was issued on their use.However, the government later claried that use of the devices, which campaigners argue is painful and cruel for animals, is not prohibited.Conservative MSP Maurice Golden said: "Over , people signed my petition to ban these harmful devices which cause so much harm to dogs."That is why it is hugely disappointing that the Government have completely failed to deliver on their promise to ban these harmful devices."This is an issue that cannot be kicked into the long grass, the Government must act urgently and outline plans that will see electric shock collars for dogs banned once and for all."Mr Golden hosted a drop-in event at the Scottish Parliament last week for MSPs to pledge their support for an outright ban.The UK Government announced plans in August to ban electronic shock collars for pets and the devices are banned in Wales.Rachel Casey, of the Dogs Trust, said: "We are disappointed that despite previously committing to effectively ban the use of electronic and other aversive training devices, a year later the Scottish Government has only issued guidance about their use."This means that Scotlands pets are not protected from the negative impacts of using these cruel devices."She said changes could be made to a dogs behaviour through positive reinforcement without the need to use the collars.Lindsay Fyffe-Jardine, of Edinburgh Dog and Cat Home, said: "We strongly believe that an outright ban on the use of shock collars is the only outcome that will ensure dogs are protected from the fear and misery these collars bring."

title: brexit-theresa-may-scraps-65-fee-for-eu-citizens
story: The Prime Minister confirmed she had scrapped the pound fee millions of EU citizens were going to have to pay as she urgedMPS to back her Brexit deal.:MPs set to start putting forward ious Brexit options ahead of next weeks Commons voteShe told MPs that thepound Settled Status fee for EU citizens will be scrapped after she had listened to concerned EU citizens living in the UK.Speaking in Parliament she said:"The Government will waive the application fee so that there is no financial barrier for any EU nationals who wish to stay."Any paid fees will be reimbursed by those that have applied.A win for @themillion  @theSNP here. Wersquove been campaigning on this since it was announced. Still many, many issues caused by the scrapping of free movement but this is positive news. https:t.co azSeJLmmThe move was welcomed by members of the Opposition.Under previous plans, now scrapped by the PM, residents living in the UK must have lived in the UK for five years and had told they would pay a fee of pound each to retain their status.:Theresa May set to reveal plan to ditch Irish backstop in bid to win over Brexit deal criticsMr Corbyn invited Mrs May to set out which of her Brexit red lines she would rub out to gain consensus.He said: "The Government still appears not to have come to terms with the scale of the defeat in the House of Commons last week."The Prime Minister seems to be going through the motions of accepting the result but in reality is in deep denial."The logic is that the Prime Minister must change her red lines because her current deal is undeliverable."So can she be clear and explicit with the House - which of her red lines is she prepared to move on "Mr Corbyn said: "There is a clear majority in this House to support a deal in principle and to respect the referendum result - but it requires the Prime Minister to face reality and accept her deal has been comprehensively defeated."He asked Mrs May to clary what "concessions" she will seek from the EU over the Irish border backstop, adding: "What makes her think that what she tried to renegotiate in December will succeed in January "This really does feel a bit like Groundhog Day."The PM said she would have further discussions with Northern Irelands DUP and others on their concerns about the Irish backstop.MPs are due to vote on any proposal next Tuesday, after the PMs original plan was defeated last Tuesday by a record-breaking  votes in the House of Commons.

title: david-cameron-only-agreed-to-hold-stupid-eu-poll-because-he-thought-it-would-never-happen
story: The astonishing claim has come from Donald Tusk in a new BBC TV documentary but denied strenuously by the former Conservative Prime Ministerrsquos top press aide.The European Council President explained Mr Cameron had told him that he did not expect to win the  General Election outright and so believed Nick Clegg, his leadership partner in the  Lib-Con coalition, would veto the Brexit vote plan as a price for another joint administration in a hung parliament.But Mr Tusk, a former Prime Minister of Poland, told the first part of ldquoInside Europe: Ten Years Of Turmoil, that when the second Lib-Con coalition failed to materialise, the UK leader was stuck with his "stupid referendum," which was designed to appease Eurosceptic backbenchers.The documentary episode, due to be broadcast on Monday January , features interviews with a swathe of political figures from all sides of the Brexit spectrum, including George Osborne, the former Chancellor, Jean-Claude Juncker, the European Commission President, and former French President Nicolas Sarkozy.Mr Cameron, who quit as PM after leading the failed Remain campaign, was the most notable figure not to take part in the documentary producers explained he had declined because he had an exclusive deal to write his memoirs.But in a frank interview, Mr Tusk described talking to the former Tory leader before the referendum, while he was trying to get concessions from EU leaders on migrant benefits in an attempt to head off Eurosceptic Tory MPs.The Council President revealed that he had warned the former PM there was "no appetite for revolution", adding: "I asked David Cameron: Why did you decide on this referendum, this - its so dangerous, so, even, stupid, you know "He told me - and I was really amazed and even shocked - that the only reason was his own party.ldquo[He explained] he felt really safe because he thought at the same time that theres no risk of a referendum because, his coalition partner, the Liberals, would block this idea of a referendum."But then, surprisingly, he won and there was no coalition partner. So, paradoxically, David Cameron became the real victim of his own victory."However, Sir Craig Oliver, the former director of communications at No , who also appears in the documentary, said Mr Tuskrsquos claims were ldquocompletely wrong.He tweeted: "David Cameron spent the whole of the  election campaign making clear he would not lead any form of government that didnt have a referendum...The coalition as excuse to bail is a myth."

title: broadband-lottery-as-study-finds-scots-get-uk-raw-deal-over-internet-speeds
story: Which  said their study shows "the urgency of improving broadband services across many parts of Scotland" - and the need to increase awareness of faster speeds, where they are available.Orkney had the slowest typical broadband speeds in the UK with just mbps.The other five Scottish areas which included in the worst  areas of the UK for speeds were Shetland , Argyll and Bute , Moray , Highlandand the Scottish Borders .:SNP ministers struggling to deliver hit % superfast broadbandThe consumer group said that broadband users in some of these areas might find it hard to carry out online banking or to use streaming services like Netflix or BBC iPlayer due to slow internet.The regulatory Ofcom set the deadline as part of a broadband universal obligationin March, last year. Also lagging behind were the Highlands , Borders , Aberdeenshire , Perth and Kinrossand Na h-Eilean Siar .At the other end of the scale, the analysis of typical broadband speeds found that the fastest local authority in Scotland and third fastest in the UK for broadband speeds was West Dunbartonshire, with an average .mpbs.It means that in what Which  called the broadband speeds lottery, downloading a film in the Orkney Islands will take around seven times longer than it would in West Dunbartonshire.:Advertised broadband speeds % slower since misleading claims rulingIn December, , the Scottish Government confirmed plans to spend pound million in the lsquoRrsquo programme which aims to make a superfast broadbandcapable network available to  per cent of Scotland by the end of .The Which  report analysing speeds in the year to September , , reveals that none of the median speeds in Scotland analysed are yet at superfast level.Alex Neill, Which  home products and services managing director said: ldquoItrsquos incredibly frustrating that so many Scots are still struggling to get a good broadband connection when so many of us rely heavily on the internet to carry out important everyday tasks.ldquoThe Scottish Government must now press ahead with plans to provide % of the homes in Scotland with a decent broadband connection and make sure that no one is at a disadvantage because of where they live.Other areas in Scotland benefiting from a faster connection included Inverclyde , Dundee City , North Lanarkshireand East Renfrewshire .Paul Wheelhouse, minister for energy, connectivity and the islands said: ldquoThis report highlights what we know ndash that it is more challenging to deliver and upgrade broadband infrastructure in rural areas. Our Reaching %programme is a plan to extend superfast broadband access to every home and business in the country in Scotland, and we have focussed procurement for R in rural areas, where it is needed most.ldquoA total of % of homes and businesses across Scotland already have access to superfast broadband, and we are investing pound million to go further. R is the only programme of its kind in the UK and will deliver a future-proofed, national fibre network that will make rural Scotland one of the best connected places anywhere in Europe, underpinning future economic growth.

title: tv-review-two-doors-down
story: ****BBC SCOTLANDrsquoS best comedy made a rare break for freedom last night, trading the usual Latimer Terrace front room of saintly Beth and soft as a  cone Eric for a hospital ward.If comedy is all about the timing, the decision to air an episode that mentioned hospital infections while investigations are continuing into the death of two patients at the QEUH in Glasgow, was an odd one. Schedulers do not have the gt of foresight, and perhaps it would not have worked to substitute another episode, but still.Christine , in for a gallbladder op, was the centre of attention last night. It is usually booze-guzzling Cathy, the Venus man trap in heels, who dominates proceedings but she left after the first scene. Although this deprived viewers of the pleasure of seeing Cathy and Michellesquare up to each other like a Caledonian Bette Davis and Joan Crawford, it gave the others a chance to shine.Christine had the pick of the lines. Politically incorrect as always, she could not praise the place or the staff highly enough before tearing them down again. ldquoEverythingrsquos disabled friendly in here. There are wee ramps everywhere. Theyrsquore a ******* nuisance.While some might have missed Cathyrsquos presence, Simon Carlyle and Gregor Sharprsquos sitcom works best as an ensemble effort, an Abigailrsquos Party blend of characters, high camp and low farce. This episode being set in a hospital, there was plenty of scope for riper material which Carlyle and Sharp could not resist. Sure enough, the revelation that Christine had an en suite bathroom duly led to Alantaking the worldrsquos loudest pee while everyone pretended not to hear Niagara Falls two feet away.Two Doors Down gets away with material like this, and the frequent swearing, because care is taken to even out the sweet and sour. When Alan comes out of the bathroom, for instance, his partner Michelle went into mummy to toddler mode, askinghe had washed his hands. ldquoBack in, she scolded. Everyone knows a couple like this.If that was not to your liking there was Christine in rare reflective mode , and Jonathan Watson, wonderful Watson, showing once again that Scottish comedy has only skimmed the surface of his talents. After his character Colin paid a heartfelt tribute to the NHS, Eric askedhe was still in Bupa. ldquoOh God aye, he replied.The finest five minutes came in a group rf about hospital woes they had known, with Michelle remembering the granny with a sparkle in her eyes. The way the scene turned out showed James McAvoy might have some competition from little sis soon on the serious drama front. As for Alanrsquos attempt to comfort her, ldquoDo ye want a tangerine , how pure dead Scottish male was that Certainly, the jokes in this fourth series are easier to see coming than before, but by this stage in the game the comedy is coming more from the characters than the situation. They can still surprise us, as several did last night, and while that remains the case this is one comedy audiences will continue to welcome through the door.Herersquos hoping it is back to business as usual next week on the terrace. The rivalry between Cathy and Michelle is hotting up nicely, and now that Colin is becoming bolder in showing how he feels about the new neighbour on the block, this series can only end badly for someone. Oh good.

title: angus-macneil-calls-on-nicola-sturgeon-to-drop-support-for-peoples-vote-and-focus-on-indyref2
story: Angus Brendan MacNeil, who represents Na-h-Eileanan an Iar, made his plea in the wake of Alex Salmondrsquos insistence that the First Minister should put an end to the "uncivil war" raging within SNP ranks and focus on making the case for Scotland leaving the UK.At the weekend, the former First Minister told his successor that with Theresa May struggling to get her Brexit plans through the Commons, there was "not likely to be a better time to force the issue" on independence.Mr MacNeil, who chairs the Commons Energy and Climate Change Committee, retweeted the findings of a poll, which showed the majority of Britons[ to  per cent] were opposed to a second Brexit referendum, which is now the SNP leadershiprsquos primary goal on Brexit.Mr MacNeil tweeted: "Oh well @theSNP you tried but #EuroRef not wanted...So now it is the referendum with the mandate #Indyref to come to fore...Change in media strategy now "The SNP won the  Holyrood election, calling for a fresh vote on independencethere was a material change in circumstances from the  referendum, making clear this would be the caseScotland was dragged out of the EU against Scotlandrsquos wishes.The SNP leadership has stalled on the timing of calling for a second independence poll with Ms Sturgeon, saying last week it would be a "matter of weeks" before she made a final decision. The Prime Minister has repeatedly made clear she would not facilitate another referendum this side of the  General Election.Last week, Keith Brown, the partyrsquos deputy leader, said it had become ldquoincreasingly clear the only way Scotlandrsquos interests can be protected and our democratic decisions respected is through independence.Yet the Nationalists are suffering their own internal stre in the wake of the Salmond row with the FM facing questions following her predecessorrsquos legal victory against the Scottish Government when the Court of Session in Edinburgh ruled as ldquounlawful its handling of sexual misconduct allegations against the former SNP leader, which he strenuously denies.On Monday night, Willie Rennie, the Scottish Liberal Democrat leader, launched an attack on Mr MacNeil, saying: ldquoItrsquos cynical in the extreme for senior Nationalists to stoke the fires of independence to distract attention away from the crises where in the SNP.The Fe MSP noted a Peoplersquos Vote was gaining support across the UK, adding: ldquoThe Nationalists need to stay on board and focus their campaigning efforts there. The lesson of Brexit is the lesson for independence: breaking up is hard to do.

title: scots-enthusiast-reveals-secret-of-the-rolls-royce-silver-ghost
story: The famous Silver Ghost, known by its registration plate AX , was built by Rolls-Royce in  and soon earned global fame for its quietness, luxuriousness and price.It is considered something of a holy grail among enthusiasts and is thought to be the most valuable motor in the world, with an insured value of pound million.Last year, Rolls-Royce launched a new, limited edition car to commemorate the history of AX , named the Silver Ghost Collection.Just  were produced and are on sale for hundreds of thousands of pounds.But a curious fact about the carrsquos famous Spirit Of Ecstasy hood ornament has come to light almost a year after it first launched ndash and one that Rolls-Royce has not even advertised to the public.The bottom of the statue on the bonnet of the  Silver Ghost Collection models contains a small copper ingot, marked with the AX  insignia of the original car.Rolls-Royce enthusiast Ruth Blair has revealed the copper is, in fact, taken from a pipe on the original  car that has been melted down and placed on to the  model in homage to the Silver Ghost.Mrs Blair, a charity fundraiser who has a farm near Cumbernauld, said she acquired copper from the original Silver Ghost after it was reconditioned in  by Rolls-Royce heritage experts Paul and Andy Wood.The brothers replaced some copper piping from the engine bay of AX  and ious steel components, and kept them for  years, waiting for an appropriate way to use them.In  they gave the metal to Mrs Blair, who at the time was creating a miniature Rolls-Royce for children that she eventually sold to raise money for charity.Realising the immense value of the parts, she sold them back to Rolls-Royce in  for an undisclosed amount of money and suggested the manufacturer create a limited edition tribute car to its most famous model.The company then commissioned  cars and has sent them all over the world to be sold to wealthy collectors, investors and enthusiasts.Last night, a sales representative of the Leven Car Company said the source of the ingot was kept a secret until salesmen could be sure a potential buyer was serious about purchasing the car.Details of the car were also kept out of the public domain to protect the Rolls-Royce brand.A spokeswoman for Rolls-Royce said: ldquoThirty-fiveof the extraordinary and exceptional Silver Ghost Collection have been created by Rolls-Royce Motor Cars.ldquoInidually, as customers purchase these cars, they are intrigued to discover the provenance of the small copper ingot at the foot of the Spirit Of Ecstasy, and are surprised and delighted at its origins.After researching the car on its release last year, Mrs Blair realised the company had not advertised that the copper at the base of its hood ornament had come from the original AX .She told The Herald she acquired and then sold the copper from the Silver Ghost, and that it had been kept a secret from Rolls-Roycersquos own potential customers.Her husband, John Blair, who is a former car salesman, travelled to the Rolls-Royce factory at Goodwood, West Sussex, while the cars were being manufactured.He learned that even the engineers working on the Silver Ghost collectionrsquos construction had not been told by the companyrsquos executives where the materials had come from.To practise creating a copper ingot, and not wishing to use the precious century-old copper, Rolls-Royce bought some of the material from a local scrapyard to create a prototype of what would become the limited edition Spirit of Ecstasy, she said.Now only one of the cars remains in the UK, at the Leven Car Company in Edinburgh.Mrs Blair still owns steel wheel assembly nuts, coach bolts and a starting handle spring from the Silver Ghost.And she says she is looking for a partner who may be able to help her rework or redevelop them.ldquoI originally gave them all the parts ndash the steel and the copper ndash and they gave me the steel parts back, she said.ldquoJohn took the parts down to Manchester, and everyone seemed to have an interest in the copper rather than the steel.ldquoIf you see a picture of AX , yoursquoll see itrsquos got circular bolts around the wheels, and thatrsquos it.ldquoThe car was restored but they tried to keep it as original as possible so they only took off parts that were well and truly gubbed.Mrs Blair also owns the registration plate  AX, which is a reversal of the famous carrsquos plate.She says she has had ldquoloads of Rolls-Royces, and that her fascination with them came from travelling in the back seat of a Rolls-Royce Corniche when she was a child.ldquoI had two brothers that were car mad, and Irsquove always loved cars, she said.

title: 17k-bottle-of-scotch-on-sale-after-maturing-for-70-years
story: Gordon  MacPhail was founded in the late th century, and was one of the first companies to acquire freshly-created spirit from Scottish distilleries and not blend it with others.The company then matured the whisky itself in barrels used to make other spirits.The so-called single-malt, which at the time made up a vanishingly small proportion of the worldrsquos whisky market, was championed by curators who wanted to develop unique flavours.The firm now has a huge collection of whiskies from historic and long-closed distilleries that it occasionally bottles and puts on the market.Now, after  years of maturing a whisky from the Glen Grant distillery, Gordon  MacPhail has uncorked the barrel and is selling bottles to customers for pound, each.For Stephen Rankin, director of prestige, whose great-grandfather John Urquhart selected the whisky for the company collection on June , , tasting Glen Grant for the first time is an ldquoemotional experience.He tried a dram from the cask with his cousin, who also works for the company.ldquoIn a nutshell, itrsquos incredibly smooth, incredibly mellow, but itrsquos got a huge amount of character and flavour, he says.ldquoWhen you drink something of this sort of age, it takes you back in time to things that were going on back then, in .ldquoYoursquore thinking about the Geneva Convention, which was to come out not long after that. It was years before we started putting men in space, and while ious things have happened, this whisky has quietly matured throughout all of that.Gordon  MacPhail competed with blended whiskies from labels such as Johnnie Walker and Chivas Regal in an approach that was considered eccentric at the time. The company refers to itself as a ldquocurator and creator,not a distiller.Mr Rankin describes the Glen Grant as having a dizzying array of flavours, including vanilla fudge, strawberries, raspberries, white stone fruit, orange peel, cinnamon, mahogany, mint and cardamom.It began le as spirit, produced by the Glen Grant distillery in Rothes, near Elgin. At the time, the distillery would have used traditional whisky-making practices and burned peat as fuel in its distillery.Gordon  MacPhail, located in Elgin, bought a cask of the spirit and began to mature it in a cask that had transported sherry from Spain. As the spirit matured into whisky, it borrowed the other spiritrsquos flavours, left over in the wood of the barrel.For the next  years, the cask stayed with the company, being checked regularly by members of the Urquhart family to measure the rate of maturation and the impact of the wood on the spirit.Last October, the family finally decided the whisky had reached its ideal maturity, and has produced  bottles from the -litre cask to be sold as part of its Private Collection range.The Private Collection is a selection of whiskies chosen by members of the Urquhart family from closed or little-known distilleries, which sell for huge amounts of money.It has a collection of whisky from  distilleries in Scotland, of which  no longer exist.Last year, a bottle of the companyrsquos  Glenlivet whisky sold at auction for more than pound,.The Glen Grant is bottled at the cask strength of . per cent in a hand-blown crystal decanter and will be sold on the market for pound,.Mr Rankin says there are three types of people who typically pay thousands for a bottle: collectors, investors, and what he calls the ldquoRegular Joes, for whom the history of a whisky and its rare flavours prove too much to resist.ldquoItrsquos like an antique, he says. ldquoIt cannot be recreated. You cannot go back to the s to remake this, and whisky back then was made dferently. People want to try things the way it was. Wersquove had regular people who probably live in suburbia, for example, but the story of the whisky will touch them on a level you canrsquot understand, because itrsquos personal to them.ldquoIt might be when their mother or father was born, or when their business was started, or when they were born. Therersquos lots of emotional tie-ins.For Mr Rankin, the emotion of drinking the  spirit comes from knowing it is members of his own family that have looked after the cask for decades.He said: ldquoMy grandfather George would have had a signicant role in the selection of whiskies, and he would have done this overseen by his father. He would then have passed on the skills to analyse and check maturing whisky to his children. All that knowledge and history has been passed down to us.

title: beauticians to host make off
story: Two north east beauticians are preparing to host their first ever amateur make up competition this weekend.The Great Amatuer ‘Make Off’ will be held at Thainstone House on Sunday, January .The competition will see  make up artists aged under compete in the style of the ‘Great British Bake Off’, only this will be a ‘make off’.The event has been organised by Julia Stronach and Alana McCrae in a bid to celebrate the skills and talent of young make up artists.Speaking to the Herald, Julia said: “We decided to host this event as there isn’t a  for young people showcase their skills, and there is a lot of talented young make up artists out there.“We will have judges on the day to look at all of the entries to keep it as fair as possible.“The competitors will be judged on technical, overall look and hygene.”This is the first event of its kind but it may not be the last as Julia explained: “The response has been very good, we’ve even had to turn people down as we couldn’t accept any more entries. One of the competitors is travelling up from Birmingham.“I think we will definitely do another one moving forward, and we might do a competition for adults too.”Although entries for the event are closed, members of the public are welcome to come along to the competition to spectate.Tickets are priced £ and £ available from www.platinumpromakeup shop.The event is being sponsored by The Nailco Nail Bar in Aberdeen.data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The temporary pop-up shop is located to the front of the JG Ross building"  Coffee shop closes for refurbishment viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: blue toon station set for fm launch
story: A popular Peterhead radio station is preparing to broadcast on FM at the end of the month.Buchan Radio will make the move to .FM towards the end of January but will still be available to stream online for listeners outside the Buchan area.The move to FM is the latest step for the Broad Street-based station, which started broadcasting online for the first time in April .Station manager Ronnie Arthur said: “We were awarded the FM licence last May and since then we have been busy pulling everything together.“Our online broadcast will continue - we have listeners around the world tuning in from Australia and America to Spain and Thailand.”Buchan Radio’s FM signal will initially reach the Buchan area but the station hopes that this will expand across Aberdeenshire in the future.Ronnie continued: “A lot of people doubted us and said that we would never get a licence but we’ve battled through and OFCOM have rewarded us with one.“We think Peterhead is ready for a new sound and a feel good station.“We are looking forward to it and we are ready to rock and roll.”Fellow station manager, John Cropley, said: “This is a dream come true.”The station will feature popular shows including Drive Time, a s show, Saturday Ceilidh, Buchan Radio Goes Country and North East Unleashed, giving local bands the opportunity to showcase their talents.It will also continue to run song requests, weather reports and road updates.Ronnie added: “We are still a community station and we rely on sponsorship and support to keep going.data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.buchanobserver webimage ..!
